game.name: Art of Fighting 3 - The Path of the Warrior / Art of Fighting - Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden
game.description: Art of Fighting 3 - The Path of the Warrior / Art of Fighting - Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden
game.title_clean: Art of Fighting 3 - The Path of the Warrior / Art of Fighting - Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden
game.plot: Art of Fighting 龍虎の拳 外伝 (c) 1996 SNK Corp.[CR](Art of Fighting - Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden)[CR]10 selectable characters battle each other in various locations in Mexico. Extremely beautiful and fluid animation courtesy of motion capture technology brings a whole new style of game-play to this popular fighting game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID: NGM-096[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player[CR]=> [A] Punch [B] Kick [C] Hard brow [D] Raz[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden was released in March 1996 in Japan.[CR]The subtitle of this game translates from Japanese as 'Dragon and Tiger Fist Side Story'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Art of Fighting 3'.[CR]In each character endings, you receive a nice hand-draw of the character on the 'Thank you for Playing' screen.[CR]The drawing Hoeh-Hoeh selects for Wang Koh San in the ending is random, there are 7 different ones.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden - PCCB-00212) on 03/04/1996.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* All characters have 2 colors, one is selected with the A button an the other one is chosen with the D button.[CR]* Play as Sinclair : Highlight Robert and press Left (or highlight Jin and press Right(x2)).[CR]* Play as Wyler : Highlight Robert and press Left(x2) (or highlight Jin and press Right).[CR]* Special Day (Birthday Gift) : Definitely one of the strangest tricks in fighting games, each character will be powered up on his birthday (able to perform Super Desperation Moves at any moment during the fight!).[CR]Kasumi Todo - March, 29[CR]Wang Koh-San - April, 17[CR]Lenny Criston - May, 20[CR]Karman Cole - June, 13[CR]Rody Births - July, 24[CR]Ryo Sakazaki - August, 2[CR]Jin-Fuha - September, 4[CR]Wyler - October, 22[CR]Sinclair - November, 14[CR]Robert Garcia - December, 25[CR]* Ultimate K.O. : Defeat an opponent in the first round by using your character's Super Desperation Move when the enemy's lifebar is 5% of less. If done correctly, you'll win the whole match in just a single round![CR]* Finish the game without losing a round to get a comical hand drawn picture of the character after the credits.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Ryuuko no Ken [Model NGM-044] (1992)[CR]2. Ryuuko no Ken 2 [Model NGM-056] (1994)[CR]3. Art of Fighting - Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden [Model NGM-096] (1996)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Object Designers : Heitarou, Black Tree, Futatsu (Futatsu!!), Higetoboin, UG, Ponda, Tohru, Pinkey-EX, Horipu (Hori-pu~?), Terarin, Kattsun, Sumiccho, Nana, Ashizawan, Satopyon, Tani Tani, Koara, Rave Man, Sasa, K. Miya, Rolly(R), Tony Oki, ??....![CR]Back Designers : Muramama Eiko, Daisuke, Wa-Da-Mo, J K, Shochan, Take-Pyon[CR]Programmers : MA2++, Yuritaro, Hiropon[CR]CG Creators : K-Asa, Aki. Yama, Demao. Sat, Seri[CR]Music Composers : Yamapy-1, Masahiko Hataya (Papaya), Shibakichi[CR]Capture Assisted by : Masa, Shin. T, Jeffrey Zoern, Raymond Ho.[CR]Producers : Takashi Nishiyama, Hiroshi Matsumoto (Finish Hiroshi)[CR]Directors : Go, Shigeri #3, Kim-Ken, Moai-Nao[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryo : Masaki Usui[CR]Robert : Mantaro Koichi[CR]Rody : Eiji Yano[CR]Lenny : Kumi Ishida[CR]Wang : Monster Maetsuka[CR]Karman : Mantaro Koichi[CR]Jin : Jai[CR]Sinclair : Harumi Ikoma[CR]Wyler : Monster Maetsuka[CR]Special Thanks : Kaori Kasai, Osamu Sato[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR][JP] SNK Neo-Geo (Apr. 26, 1996) "Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden [Model NGH-096]"[CR][JP] SNK Neo-Geo CD (June 14, 1996) "Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden [Model NGCD-096]"[CR][JP] SNK Neo-Geo CD (June 14, 1996) "Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden [Limited Edition] [Model NGCD-0960]"[CR][JP] Sony PlayStation 2 (May 11, 2006) "Ryuuko no Ken - Ten Chi Jin [NeoGeo Online Collection Vol.4] [Model SLPS-25610]"[CR][JP] Sony PlayStation 2 (June 21, 2007) "Ryuuko no Ken - Ten Chi Jin [NeoGeo Online Collection The Best] [Model SLPS-25790]"[CR]

game.name: Asteroids Deluxe (rev 3)
game.plot: Asteroids Deluxe (c) 1981 Atari, Incorporated.[CR]Asteroids Deluxe is a 1 or 2-player game with an X-Y or vector-generator monitor. The game depicts a third-person view of a player's spaceship battling to destroy asteroids, flying saucers and enemy ships or 'death stars' (shaped like clusters of triangles). When hit, the asteroids and death stars will break into progressively smaller pieces. [CR]Players can put up an octagon-shaped 'shield' to temporarily protect their spaceship. However, this shield wears out with use. [CR]Large asteroids appear and drift in from the outer edges of the display. By pressing the ROTATE LEFT and ROTATE RIGHT pushbuttons on the control panel, the player may aim a spaceship toward any of the asteroids. The player uses the FIRE pushbutton to shoot at the asteroids and other objects. [CR]When shot, each large asteroid divides into two medium-sized asteroids, and the game adds 20 points to the player's score. Medium-sized asteroids, when shot, divide into two small-sized asteroids, and the game awards 50 points to the player. When shot the smallest asteroid disappears and the game adds 100 points to the player's score. [CR]In addition to asteroids, the players can score points for shooting the various enemy ships. When hit, the large ships ('death stars' shaped like hexagons) score 50 points and break into three diamond shapes. The medium-sized enemy or diamond, when hit, grants the player 100 points and breaks into two small triangular pieces. These small pieces disappear when the player hits them, and the score increases by 200 points. [CR]At any time during game play, a flying saucer may appear from either side of the display. The game awards players 200 points for shooting a large saucer and 1,000 points for a small saucer (the latter is a smaller target for players, though not any faster moving than the large one. It also shoots more accurately). [CR]The player's objective in the game is to shoot and destroy as many asteroids, saucers, and enemy ships as possible before all his or her spaceships are destroyed. A ship is destroyed if an asteroid, saucer or enemy ship smashes into it, or if a flying saucer shoots it. To prevent losing a ship, the player may press the THRUST pushbutton to move out of the path of an oncoming object. [CR]As an emergency maneuver, a player can press the Shields button. An octagon will then appear around the player's ship as protection from all enemies. For challenge the shield power lasts only about 10 seconds, but the power is renewed with each ship. The amount of shielding power available is shown by the brightness of the octagon (dim means almost exhausted power). [CR]- CAST OF CHARACTERS - [CR]Spaceship - This is you, the player. You can rotate 360 degrees, fire bullets, thrust forward in any direction, and use the shields if you feel you are in danger. [CR]Large Asteroid - These are the large rocks that fill the screen at the beginning of each stage. Hitting one with a bullet will break it apart in to two Medium Asteroids. [CR]Medium Asteroid - Slightly smaller than Large Asteroids, but faster moving, shooting one of these will result in two Small Asteroids. [CR]Small Asteroid - These are the smallest and fastest rocks on the screen. If a bullet hits one of these, it will vaporize. [CR]Hexagon - This addition to Asteroids appears when the stage is nearly free of rocks. It floats in one direction until it is shot. [CR]Diamond - When the Hexagon is shot it breaks up in to three separate diamonds. These begin to track and slowly follow you. [CR]Triangle - When a Diamond is shot it breaks up in to two separate triangles. These will move very quickly and zero in on you if you don't destroy them fast enough. [CR]Large Saucer - Large flying saucers appear on the screen from time to time, randomly firing shots around the screen. Approximately one out of every four shots will be aimed directly at your ship. They will also target Hexagons if any are on the screen at the same time. [CR]Small Saucer - The small saucers are deadlier than the large variety. They are much more precise with their shots, and are more likely to kill you. Eliminate them quickly or get out of their range.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]This particular machine was released in three different formats; an upright, a cabaret, and a cocktail, with the upright being the most common, and the cabaret being the least common. All three versions were nearly pin compatible with an original "Asteroids" board-set, only a few wires had to be swapped.[CR]* The upright was a rather interesting looking design that actually bulged out toward the player from the control panel on up. Atari went all out with the side-art on this one, it completely covers the sides from the floor to the top of the machine (it is a scene of a ship in an asteroid field, similar to the one on "Asteroids", but more detailed). The control panel layout is a little more subdued than the red, white, and blue monstrosity on the original "Asteroids". Just a dark surface, a few instructions, and some buttons (this title, like the original, did not use a joystick, although it plays well with one).[CR]* The cocktail version was almost identical in appearance to the original "Asteroids" cocktail (and just about every other Atari cocktail). It was black and woodgrain, with only a minimum of ornamentation behind the glass.[CR]* The cabaret version (a cabaret is a mini upright that is less than five feet tall), is an ugly little creature, with woodgrain sides and a black front. The nameplate is down low on the machine near the coin mechs (which makes the game hard to identify at first).[CR]* Upright dimensions : 71in. (180.34cm) high x 26,75in. (67.95cm) wide x 25.25in. (64.14cm) deep. Weight : 313 lbs (140.85 kg). Monitor : 19in. QuadraScan.[CR]* Cabaret dimensions : 54.25in. (137.79cm) high x 20,44in. (51.91cm) wide x 23.75in. (60.32cm) deep. Weight : 193 lbs (86.85 kg). Monitor : 15in. QuadraScan.[CR]* Cocktail dimensions : adjustable from 21.5in. to 27in. high x 32in. (80.5cm) wide x 24in. (60cm) deep. Weight : 164 lbs (73.8 kg). Monitor : 15in. Quadrascan.[CR]Game ID : 0351xx[CR]Main CPU : MOS Technology M6502 (@ 1.512 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Discrete, POKEY (Pot Keyboard Integrated Circuit)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 256 x 231 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 60.00 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 32768[CR]Players : 2[CR]Buttons : 5[CR]=> LEFT, RIGHT, FIRE, THRUST, SHIELD[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Asteroids Deluxe was released in March 1981. [CR]The original "Asteroids" proved to be wildly popular, but there was one problem. The game was simply too easy for expert players (many people could play for hours on a single quarter). So Atari decided to make a more difficult sequel, Asteroids Deluxe. They succeeded a little too well, and had to scale the difficulty back after their initial version proved to be too difficult for the average player. This game was created out of modified "Asteroids" code. At the same time this game was being produced, "Space Duel" was in the works, but was shelved as Asteroids Deluxe was green-lighted for production. Despite its similarities to the hugely popular original, Asteroids Deluxe was a commercial flop and Atari later released "Space Duel" to moderate success. [CR]Asteroids Deluxe features modified game-play intentionally designed to challenge players who had mastered the original "Asteroids" : [CR]1) The addition of new ships. When hit, the large ships ('death stars' shaped like hexagons) break into three diamond shapes. The medium-sized enemy or diamond, when hit, breaks into two small triangular pieces. These small pieces disappear when the player hits them. The diamond and triangular ships pursue the player's ship until killed. [CR]2) The small and large UFO's have been improved : [CR]a) Their shots now 'wrap-around' the screen. This means that a shot fired off the right or left side will re-enter the screen on the left or right side. [CR]b) The accuracy of the large UFO's shots have been improved. Now every one out of four shots are aimed at the player's spaceship. If there are no other targets, all shots go toward the player's spaceship. [CR]3) The player's ship was redesigned to include two side fins and a narrower body, keeping the overall ship dimensions identical to the original game. The ship has the same maximum velocity as in "Asteroids", but can accelerate twice as fast. [CR]4) The high score now 'rolls over' at 999,999 points instead of 99,999 points. [CR]5) A graphic overlay has been added to give the game more of a feeling of depth. It also makes it slightly harder to see the vector graphics. [CR]6) The hyperspace button has been replaced by a shield. The shield lasts 10-12 seconds per spaceship and cannot be recharged. [CR]7) Firing is now automatic, holding down the fire button will release a maximum of four shots (on screen) at a time. [CR]Although the attract screen claims a 1980 copyright, the game was officially introduced in March of 1981. The front glass on the upright was originally square with the cabinet - this produced an unpleasant 'glare' on the screen. Atari later released a 'glare reduction kit' which provided an angled glass frontage to be fitted onto the cabinet thereby reducing the glare. Once applied, the kit enclosed the speaker which resulted in deeper base tones. [CR]Approximately 22,300 units were produced. [CR]John McAllister hold the official record for this game with 3,333,360 points set February 12, 2009. [CR]An Asteroids Deluxe unit appears in the 1982 movie 'Tron', in the 1982 movie 'The Thing' and in the 1984 movie 'Night of the Comet'. [CR]An Asteroids Deluxe upright cabinet appears in the Judas Priest music video 'Freewheel Burning'. [CR]In 1982, Atari released a set of 12 collector pins including : "Missile Command", "Battle Zone", "Tempest", "Asteroids Deluxe", "Space Duel", "Centipede", "Gravitar", "Dig Dug", "Kangaroo", "Xevious", "Millipede" and "Food Fight".[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]There are two versions of the software; the original release proved to be so difficult that Atari released a revised version that had easier game-play. This new version was originally introduced in Europe and is often referred to as the 'European Version'. Determining the version can be discerned by noting the first appearance of a 'death star' - in the original version this is near the end of the second wave; in the revised version it appears near the end of the first wave and moves much more slowly.[CR][B]Scoring[/B][CR]Large Asteroids : 20 points[CR]Medium Asteroids : 50 points[CR]Small Asteroids : 100 points[CR]'Death Star' (Hexagon Shaped Ship) aka 'Snowflake' : 50 points[CR]Diamond Shaped Ship : 100 points[CR]Triangular Shaped Ship : 200 points[CR]Large Saucer : 200 points[CR]Small Saucer : 1,000 points[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* When you start the game, your spaceship will be in the middle of the screen with four large asteroids heading toward your ship. After all the rocks are destroyed, the next round begins. The number of initial large asteroids depends on the round number : [CR]Round 1 : 4 [CR]Round 2 : 5 [CR]Round 3 : 6 [CR]Round 4 : 7 [CR]Round 5 : 8 [CR]Round 6 and up : 9 [CR]Your job is to blast those rocks, however, when you blast them, they break up into two medium rocks. Blasting a medium rock gives you two small rocks. Note : There is an exception to this rule. The game program only allows 24 asteroids on the screen at any one time. If the screen already contains 24 asteroids of any size, then when you shoot a large asteroid it breaks up into only one medium asteroid, and when you shoot a medium asteroid it breaks up into only one small asteroid. You can completely destroy a large asteroid with only three shots instead of seven when the screen is filled up like this. [CR]In addition, you have to contend with large and small saucers and the 'death stars'. On the first couple of screens, you can sit in the middle and blast rocks. Be aware that a saucer will enter which will cause you to move lest you be hit by its shots. In addition : [CR]1) You can have four shots on the screen at any one time. This is useful for when you are blasting rocks at close range. You can pretty much drill them to dust. [CR]2) Your shots 'wrap around' the screen. This means any shot that goes past the edge of the screen will reappear on the opposite side traveling the same direction. The saucers also have 'wrap around' shots. [CR]* After 10,000 points, the small saucer becomes a permanent part of the game. You can no longer sit in one place since the small saucer is able to track your ship and take you out with the first or second shot. [CR]* Your shields have a maximum life expectancy of 17 seconds. Each collision with a rock takes away about six seconds of shield time. Once your shield runs down, it can not be recharged. In other words : use your shields as little as possible. [CR]* Although there is danger from the rocks and saucers, you can also be a danger to yourself. Use the thrust carefully or you will find yourself careening out of control on the screen. Some players get really good, however, moving around and shooting. [CR]* For those desired high scores, you can use the hunting trick. It goes something like this : [CR]1) After 10,000 points, the small saucers appear. They are worth 1,000 points apiece. First, blast every rock until you have one small rock left. [CR]2) Go sit in the upper left or right corner of the game screen. [CR]3) If the small saucer appears from the side you are on, then you can blast it before it gets off a shot. If it appears on the opposite side, use the shot 'wrap around' to take care of it. Some people have done this for hours on end and racked up scores in the millions. Of course, it takes a long time at 1,000 points a pop. [CR]4) Also keep in mind that the small saucer can wrap shots so you may have to move out of danger. [CR]5) Unlike in "Asteroids", the small saucers fire a greater number of shots so hunting is more of a challenge. [CR]6) After 60,000 points, the accuracy of both UFO's goes up dramatically. [CR]* The 'death stars' make their appearance in either the first or second wave : [CR]1) It appears on the screen just lazily floating around. It can only be broken open by laser fire (yours or the saucer's). [CR]2) Once open, the pieces pursue the player. Hitting one of the diamond-shaped pieces breaks it into two triangular pieces. [CR]3) The best way to defeat this enemy is to accelerate forward, then turn quickly while shooting. This causes you to fly backwards while shooting at the pieces.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Asteroids (1979)[CR]2. Asteroids Deluxe (1981)[CR]3. Space Duel (1982)[CR]4. Blasteroids (1987)[CR]5. Asteroids (1998, PC, PS; 1999, GBC; 2000, Mac) [CR]6. Asteroids Hyper 64 (1999, N64)[CR]7. Asteroids Gunner (2011, App Store)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Programmed by : Dave Shepperd[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (2001) "Atari Anniversary Edition Redux [Model SLUS-01427]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [US] (July 2, 2001) "Atari Anniversary Edition [Model T-15130N]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (March 1, 2002) "Atari Anniversary Edition Redux [Model SLES-03808]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX [US] (November 16, 2004) "Atari Anthology [Model 26084]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (November 22, 2004) "Atari Anthology [Model SLUS-21076]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX [EU] (November 26, 2004) "Atari Anthology" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (February 18, 2005) "Atari Anthology [Model SLES-53061]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX [JP] (August 4, 2005) "Atari Anthology [Model B7X-00001]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX 360 [XBLA] [US] [EU] (November 28, 2007) [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [US] (December 19, 2007) "Atari Classics Evolved [Model ULUS-10325]" [CR]Sony PSP [AU] (March 7, 2008) "Atari Classics Evolved"[CR]Nintendo DS [US] (March 8, 2011) "Atari Greatest Hits Vol.2 [Model NTR-BR7E-USA]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]BBC Micro Model B [EU] (1984, Atarisoft) [CR]Atari ST [EU] (1987) [CR]PC [MS Windows, CD-ROM] [US] (April 4, 1998) "Atari Arcade Hits 2" [CR]PC [MS Windows, CD-ROM] [EU] (2000) "Atari Arcade Hits 2" [CR]PC [MS Windows, CD-ROM] [US] (July 9, 2001) "Atari Anniversary Edition" [CR]PC [MS Windows, CD-ROM] [EU] (December 14, 2001) "Atari Anniversary Edition" [CR]PC [MS Windows, CD-ROM] [US] (November 11, 2003) "Atari - 80 Classic Games in One! [Model 25069J]" [CR]PC [MS Windows, CD-ROM] [EU] (June 10, 2005) "Atari - 80 Classic Games in One! [Replay]" [CR]* Others : [CR]Mobile Phones [US] (September 7, 2004) [CR]Atari Flashback 2 [US] (2005) [CR]Nokia N-Gage [US] (February 2006) "Atari Masterpieces Vol. II" [CR]Nokia N-Gage [EU] (March 30, 2006) "Atari Masterpieces Vol. II" [CR]Atari Flashback 2+ [US] (2010) : Atari 2600 version [CR]Windows Mobile [US] (February 23, 2011) "Game Room - Asteroids Deluxe" [CR]Apple Store [US] (2012) "Atari Greatest Hits" [CR]Google Play [US] (2012) "Atari Greatest Hits"[CR]

game.name: Astro Blaster (version 3)
game.plot: Astro Blaster (c) 1981 Sega.[CR]Astro Blaster is a 1- or 2-player game in which players must advance through squadrons of alien ships in an attempt to dock with the mother ship. Players move their ship left or right and shoot at attacking squadrons. A special time warp allows the player to slow down the alien space ships and their laser fire, while maintaining his own ship and laser fire at normal speed.[CR]As players go through the game play, each step is directed by the voice of mission control. Mission control keeps players informed of fuel status, provides a countdown on warp, keeps track of the number of ships remaining, and monitors the player's laser temperature.[CR]As players enter each new sector they encounter a different number of alien squadrons. Players must destroy all ships in each squadron to pass through the sector. One squadron of rockets is extremely difficult to destroy, but players can pass through this squadron by hitting a few enemy ships. Once a player has destroyed all the squadrons in that sector, he enters an asteroid belt. He must maneuver and shoot his way through the asteroids to reach the mother ship. If fuel is critically low when the player enters the asteroid belt, he can receive extra fuel by shooting the red fireballs interspersed among the asteroids. After passing through the asteroid belt, the player's ship docks with the mother ship and refuels.[CR]There are 29 different alien squadrons players encounter as they move through the different sectors. Every new sector increases in difficulty with different numbers of squadrons in each sector. Each alien ship has its own individualized sounds, movements and firing capability.[CR]During their game, players must keep track of fuel consumption. As the player's ship moves through the sector, it consumes fuel. The player must ensure he has enough fuel to advance through the sector and dock with the mother ship. Extra fuel can only be obtained by shooting red fireballs or docking with the mother ship. The screen also displays the laser temperature. As players fire, the laser temperature rises. When they cease firing it cools down. If the laser overheats, players lose their laser fire until it cools down.[CR]By depressing the warp button, players slow down the enemy ships and their laser fire while maintaining his own at normal speed. Players receive one warp per ships and are awarded one warp upon docking, if he has used his warp in the previous sector.[CR]Each alien ship destroyed carries a different point value. Players also receive double points for destroying an alien ship when their fuel is in the red. To add further excitement, there are 25 tasks that a player performs during the course of the game and receives a secret bonus. Players do not know what these tasks are, but a good player will keep track. The 25 tasks are consistent throughout the game. Players also receive a bonus for any fuel they have left when they dock with the mother ship.[CR]With a two-player game, players alternate at the conclusion of each sector, not after each ship. Players receive 3 to 5 ships, which is operator adjustable. The game is over when a player runs out of fuel, loses all his ships, or crashes while attempting to dock with the mother ship. The top three scores are displayed and the game ranks players from 1 to 99.[CR]PLAY INSTRUCTIONS :[CR]1. Shoot enemy space ships for points.[CR]2. Shoot fire balls for extra fuel.[CR]3. Use warp to slow down enemy ships and bombs (only once per sector or ship).[CR]4. Discover how to earn secret bonuses for extra points.[CR]5. Dock with mother ship to refuel after each sector.[CR]6. Game over when you run out of ships or fuel.[CR]7. Laser will not fire while overheated.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Sega G80 Raster hardware[CR]Main CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 3.867 Mhz), I8035 (@ 208 Khz)[CR]Sound Chips : Discrete circuitry, SP0250 (@ 3.12 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Vertical[CR]Video resolution : 224 x 256 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 60.00 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 64[CR]Players : 2[CR]Buttons : 4 (LEFT, RIGHT, FIRE, WARP)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Astro Blaster was released in March 1981.[CR]Astro Blaster was one of the big contributions from Sega/Gremlin. Utilizing speech synthesis, the game attracted players by stating 'Fighter pilots needed in sector wars, play Astro Blaster'. During game play, the game gave you different advice such as 'Alert, alert, invaders in sector 1, player 1 to battle stations', 'Fuel status marginal', or 'Warp activated, 10, 9, 8,...' to name a few.[CR]Astro Blaster wasn't the first game to introduce speech synthesis in a game, that honor goes to Taito's "Stratovox". Astro Blaster, though, challenged the player to go through seven sectors with a varying amount of waves within each sector. Astro Blaster was an extremely challenging game, it developed a solid following. It wasn't as popular as "Frogger", which was released later on, but it still had a solid showing and redefined how space shooters could be made more challenging. Other notable games released in this year were "Donkey Kong", "Galaga", "Vanguard", and "Wizard of Wor".[CR]The bonuses in this game were actually bugs that would appear if certain events took place. Rather than 'fix' the bugs, Gary Shannon changed them to bonus 'features'.[CR]Gus Pappas holds the official record for this game with 299,100 points on November 20, 1982.[CR]In Sega's Dreamcast 1999 video game "Shenmue", an Astro Blaster cabinet can be seen in the YOU Arcade in Dobuita, but it has an 'out of order' label on it and is not playable. Its possible it was originally playable and had to be removed for some reason, but it is perhaps there simply for the sake of realism; Shenmue is set in 1986/87, so even then it would be considered an old game.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Three versions of Astro Blaster were released. The first version was deemed too difficult to play. Version 2 was released to remedy this situation and to be a little more descriptive in the games instructions. Version 3 was basically the EASY version of Astro Blaster. All 3 versions had some things in common :[CR]1) All the different alien spacecraft were in all of the versions, it was just their order of appearance that made a difference.[CR]2) The secret bonuses were common to all three versions. Just because a sector had different waves didn't mean the bonuses for specific events were changed.[CR]3) Each had a high score table that held the 99 top scores.[CR]It was easy to spot a version one machine. The instructions were displayed on the screen. When you inserted your money, you just had to press the 1- or 2-player button to start the game.[CR]On versions 2 and 3, after you inserted your money, a blue screen came up and basically told you to press the 1- or 2-player button.. It also explained some of the rules while in attract mode. The order of the alien attackers is what determined version two and three.[CR][B]Scoring[/B][CR]NOTE : During fuel status critical, everything in the game is double points.[CR]AMOEBAS : 70 Points[CR]BLUE&RED DISCS : 70 Points[CR]BLUE&RED SPIRALS : 110 Points[CR]BLUE&RED TRIANGLE : 100 Points[CR]BLUE DIAMOND : 110 Points[CR]BLUE DISC : 60 Points[CR]BLUE OVALS : 120 Points[CR]BLUE HEXAGON : 110 Points[CR]BLUE UFO'S : 160/80 Points[CR]BLUE X's : 90 Points[CR]GALAXIANS : 70/110 Points[CR]GREEN DOUBLE ARROWS : 90 Points[CR]METEOR : 60 Points[CR]ORANGE&PURPLE SPINNERS : 80/110 Points[CR]ORANGE ARROWS : 100 Points[CR]ORANGE CRYSTALS : 110 Points[CR]ORANGE DART : 40/70 Points[CR]ORANGE SAUCER : 50/100 Points[CR]RED-RINGED GLOBES : 100 Points[CR]RUBBER BANDS : 70 Points[CR]WHITE BLOCK : 70 Points[CR]WHITE BOATS : 90 Points[CR]WHITE SQUARES : 100 Points[CR]WHITE WINGS : 60 Points[CR]YELLOW BIRD : 70 Points[CR]YELLOW DOUBLE DIAMONDS : 80 Points[CR]You also get 100 points per asteroid you take out at the end of the sector.[CR]You also get a bonus for fuel remaining when you dock with the mother ship.[CR]You get a bonus for fuel remaining when you dock with the mother ship, awarded at 10 points per pixel of fuel.[CR]Secret Bonuses :[CR]Number 01, bonus 2,000 points. Complete the asteroid field without missing any fireballs.[CR]Number 03, bonus 1,000 points. Shoot all enemies without missing.[CR]Number 04, bonus 700 points. Shoot all enemies before they wrap around to the other side of the screen, during waves that have the enemies that fly horizontally or diagonally.[CR]Number 09, bonus 500, 700, 900, 1,000 or 1,500 points. Don't move at all when docking with the mother ship (1,000 points for a PERFECTLY centered approach, 1,500 points for 'the paint scraper', when you brush a docking clamp of the mother ship).[CR]Number 12, bonus 700 points. Shoot all enemies before any escape the screen through the bottom (certain waves only).[CR]Number 13, bonus 500 points. Shoot all enemies in proper order in sector 1.[CR]Number 14, bonus 1,000 points. Shoot all enemies in proper order in sector 2.[CR]Number 15, bonus 1,500 points. Shoot all enemies in proper order in sector 3.[CR]Number 16, bonus 2,000 points. Shoot all enemies in proper order in sector 4.[CR]Number 17, bonus 2,500 points. Shoot all enemies in proper order in sector 5.[CR]Number 18, bonus 3,000 points. Shoot all enemies in proper order in sector 6.[CR]Number 19, bonus 3,500 points. Shoot all enemies in proper order in sector 7.[CR]Number 22, bonus 600 points. Never get laser temperature critical during the sector (awarded before docking).[CR]Number 25, bonus 500 points. Not dying during the sector (awarded before docking).[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* When you start the game, your star ship will be in the middle of the screen. The computer voice will state 'Alert, alert, invaders sector 1, player 1, battle stations'. With that, you are ready to rock and roll. Before you start your game, be sure of what version machine you are playing so you can get yourself prepared. Since each version alters the order of the aliens, it's not good to be prepared for one attack and a totally different attack comes along.[CR]* Although the computer voice can be annoying at times, it also gives you very valuable information. This will actually help you to concentrate more on destroying aliens then constantly looking at your gauges. Some helpful things the voice will tell you are :[CR]1) When your fuel status hits marginal and critical.[CR]2) When your laser temperature is approaching critical.[CR]3) The countdown after you activate warp.[CR]* Fuel is a very precious commodity in this game. If you run out of fuel, your game is over regardless of how many star ships you have left. Learn how to maximize your fuel usage because in the later sectors that have a lot of waves, you will be running on empty. Some other fuel facts :[CR]1) When you activate warp, only the enemies on the screen slow down. Your fuel supply continues to burn away in REAL time.[CR]2) When fuel status marginal is announced, you have approximately 25 seconds of fuel remaining.[CR]3) When fuel status critical is announced, you have approximately 8 seconds of fuel remaining.[CR]4) Shooting the fireballs in the asteroid wave will get you 3 more seconds of fuel.[CR]5) You score double points during fuel status critical.[CR]6) At the end of each sector, you will be re-fueled when you dock with the mothership.[CR]7) Losing a star ship doesn't replenish your fuel supply.[CR]* The warp button can be a blessing or a curse depending on how you use it. You only get one warp per sector or one per star ship. This works fine on the lower sectors that only have a few waves. On the higher sectors, though, you must plan (if possible) the best place to utilize it. Some tips :[CR]1) If it is used on an enemy that goes across the screen, wait until they are halfway across before activating the warp. This way, you can get them all before your warp time runs out.[CR]2) If used on the diagonal flying aliens, again, wait until a lot of them are out before activating.[CR]3) For other aliens, make sure they are mostly on the screen. Sometimes, these aliens disappear off screen and if you activated your warp too early, it will be wasted while they hang around outside of the playing area.[CR]* There are no safe places in this game so you must always be on the look out for not only the aliens dropping on you, but also their laser fire.[CR]* Speaking of laser fire, your ship is equipped with a powerful laser cannon. There is no limit to the amount of shots you can fire, but there is a catch. The cannon heats up with each shot fired. It will overheat if you fire too many shots too quickly, and you will have to wait about eight seconds for it to cool off before you can fire it again. Some ways to prevent overheating :[CR]1) Make your shots count. Don't hold down the fire button to take out the aliens. Shoot to kill, not to warn.[CR]2) If you must do multiple shots, do it in short bursts. Your laser heats up much faster then it cools down.[CR]3) If you do overheat, just avoid the aliens and their fire until your laser is operational again.[CR]* Docking is the easiest way to get a lot of points. You need to set yourself up after the last of the asteroids in order to get those points. Moving your ship during docking procedures will prevent you from getting any docking bonus. The most points are from the 'Paint Scraper' method : Line up your left engine over the C in SECTOR. It will look like you will collide with the left docking arm but you will barely squeeze by. Thus, you now have 1,500 points.[CR]* Also, if you destroy your star ship during docking, your game will be over regardless of the number of men you have left.[CR]* Always expect the unexpected in this game. Sometimes the aliens will do things or make moves you haven't seen before. The best way to counter this is to always be on guard.[CR]* After sector seven, the sectors repeat again. Also, the score 'rolls over' at 99,990. Many players will intentionally get themselves killed when they get close to this score in order to claim the number one position on the board.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Designed & programmed by : Gary Shannon, Barbara Michalec[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [US] (November 16, 2006) as an unlockable extra in "Sega Genesis Collection [Model ULUS-10192]" [CR]Sony PSP [EU] (February 2, 2007) as an unlockable extra in "Sega Mega Drive Collection [Model ULES-00556]" [CR]Sony PSP [AU] (February 8, 2007) as an unlockable extra in "Sega Mega Drive Collection [Model ULES-00556]"[CR]

game.name: Astro Invader
game.plot: Astro Invader (c) 1980 Stern Electronics.[CR]Export release. Game developed in Japan. See "Kamikaze" for more information about the game itself.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in June 1980.[CR]This game appears in Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers music video for the song 'You Got Lucky' (1982).[CR]Fred Pastore of Medford, Massachusetts, holds the official record for this game with 56,330 points on June 4, 2006.[CR]An Italian bootleg of this game is known as "Kosmo Killer".[CR]

game.name: Athena
game.plot: Athena (c) 1986 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].[CR]This is a pretty hard platform game where you take the role of Athena fighting your way through different worlds inhabited by all kinds of different enemies, ranging from moving pears to huge golems and flying devils.[CR]You start out with nothing more than your feet to fight with and no more protection than Athena's underwear (she actually loses her dress in the intro to the first world) but can collect a huge number of different weapons and armour, as well as a great number of power-ups ranging from the usual more-power-for weapon or armour, through boots that allow her to jump higher and wings for flying, to one where Athena becomes a semi-god and actually growths to twice her usual size and gets a huge burning sword and full armour.[CR]The worlds are filled with stone blocks that can be smashed when searching for secrets and items, as well as several levels connected by ladders or other means of transportation.[CR]Athena is a great game, and will give even the most hardened platform-player a real challenge, for it is NOT an easy game, even with the dip switches in 'Easy' mode.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : 'UP'[CR]Main CPU : (2x) Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : (2x) YM3526 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 4-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> Sword, Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Athena was released in July 1986.[CR]The main character, Athena, appears in The King of Fighters series.[CR]The 'Athena' logo on the title screen appears in 1991's "Sengoku" by SNK. In level 2, there is a store called 'Boutique Athena' in the background with the original 'Athena' logo.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Test mode : hold START during machine boot.[CR]* Something not found in the manual to this game is that there exists a 'secret' mode of the game - if you set dip switch 7 of bank 2 to 'ON' you will get one life less than usual (2 instead of 3 or 5), but the life meter will start at 22 and not 12 or 14 which is the standard. This will make the game much more interesting.[CR]* Every time you die you loose every equipment you collected up to that point, unless you also have a 'K' Item in your inventory. If you have it, when you die you will only loose the 'K' but keep the rest of the items.[CR]* There is a secret level that can be reached collecting a magic key on the Ice, Hell or Sky world. Other may exists. This world is called 'World of Labyrinth'.[CR]* When you complete the 'World of labyrinth', you will meet an angel. Do NOT attack her, but wait until she drops an harp. If you collect it, it will work as a perpetual 'K' item, and you will never loose your items again when you die.[CR]* When you complete the 'World of labyrinth', you will be returned to the level following to the one you picked up the key on.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Athena (1986)[CR]2. Psycho Soldier (1987)[CR]3. Athena - Full Throttle (2006, Mobile Phones)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Nintendo Famicom (1987, "Athena [Model SFX-AT]")[CR]* Computers :[CR]Commodore C64 (1987)[CR]Sinclair ZX Spectrum (1987)[CR]

game.name: Avenging Spirit
game.plot: Avenging Spirit (c) 1991 Jaleco.[CR]While walking out with his girlfriend the game's hero is ambushed by unknown enemies who snatch his girlfriend and shoot the hero dead. Now, as a wandering spirit with the ability to possess almost anybody he comes across, the hero is summoned by his girlfriend's father and given a mission to save her from the mysterious crime syndicate that holds her hostage. Only then can the hero rest in peace.[CR]The player's character 'inhabits' a body with which to combat the game's enemies. When that body is killed, providing there is a living enemy nearby (other than that of a boss) the player can posses them and continue playing. Each time this is done, it costs the player some of their 'spirit energy'. Should the hero die when there are no enemies close by for the player to possess; the game is over.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Jaleco Mega System 1-B hardware[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 7 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2151 (@ 3.5 Mhz), (2x) OKI6295 (@ 30.303 Khz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> [A] Fire, [B] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in May 1991.[CR]This game is known in Japan as "Phantasm".[CR]A Korean bootleg/hack of this game is known as "Monky Elf".[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Good ending : you must find the three keys to unlock the door in which your girlfriend is held hostage in order to see the good ending.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Total Planner : Toku[CR]Game Designer : Myaa[CR]Programmer : T. Hata[CR]Character Designers : Sanbo, H. Mamoru[CR]B.G. Designers : Seven Star, C 57[CR]Sound Producer : Tykoon Mori[CR]Sound Composer : Studio O.K.[CR]Special Thanks To : Miyuki-Chan, Dark Elf[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Nintendo Game Boy (1992)[CR]

game.name: B.C. Kid / Bonk's Adventure / Kyukyoku!! PC Genjin
game.description: B.C. Kid / Bonk's Adventure / Kyukyoku!! PC Genjin
game.title_clean: B.C. Kid / Bonk's Adventure / Kyukyoku!! PC Genjin
game.plot: Kyokyoku !! PC Genjin - Special Arcade Version (c) 1994 Kaneko Company, Limited.[CR]A platform game, based on the NEC PC Engine game of the same name, consisting of 21 stages fighting dinosaurs and other creatures.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : (2x) OKI6295 (@ 12 Khz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> [A] Head butt, [B] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]This game is known outside Japan as "Bonk's Adventure - Arcade Version" and in Europe as "B.C. Kid".[CR]This game had a ticket payout mechanism meaning you could also win cheesy prizes.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]* In the Korean version titlescreen, the 'KANEKO' standard logo is replaced by 'KA' with a cat (which is pronounced 'NEKO' in Japanese).[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Bonk attacks enemies by "bonking" them with his large, invincible forehead. Bonk starts the game with three hearts' worth of health, which are depleted to blue as Bonk takes damage, and three extra lives. Bonk's health can be restored in increments by collecting fruits and vegetables.[CR]Bonk can also collect pieces of meat as power-ups; these lend him special abilities and make him stronger. There are three stages of power-up: his normal self, a second stage during which he can stun enemies by pounding on the ground, and a third stage where he becomes temporarily invulnerable. Meat can be found in two varieties: big meat and small meat. The effects of meat are additive but wear off over time. A small meat gives Bonk the second stage of meat power but will eventually decay into the first stage of meat power, and then back into regular Bonk. Eating a small meat while in stage two will put Bonk into the third, invincible stage of meat power. And eating either size of meat while in the third stage of meat power-up will reset the timer on Bonk's meat power.[CR]Bonk can occasionally collect red heart power-ups that refill an entire heart worth of health, or even more rarely, a large red heart, which restores all of Bonk's missing health. There are also two rare, blue heart power-ups in the game which will increase Bonk's maximum health by one heart.[CR]Bonking an enemy will typically knock it backward and slightly into the air. Defeating an enemy yields points and also releases a small "smiley" power-up. Bonk's smileys are totaled at the end of each stage after defeating the boss of that stage. The player is given additional points and a caveman type congratulation based on how many smileys were collected.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. PC Genjin [Model HC89024] (1989, PCE)[CR]2. PC Genjin 2 [Model HC91043] (1991, PCE)[CR]3. GB Genjin [Model DMG-GKJ] (1992, GB)[CR]4. PC Genjin 3 [Model HC93063] (1993, PCE)[CR]5. GB Genjin 2 [Model DMG-RJJ] (1994, GB)[CR]6. Kyokyoku !! PC Genjin - Special Arcade Version (1994, ARC)[CR]7. Super Genjin [Model SHVC-ZH] (1994, SFC)[CR]8. Super Genjin 2 [Model SHVC-AZ7J-JPN] (1995, SFC)[CR]9. PC Genjin (2002, GC)[CR]

game.plot: B.Rap Boys (c) 1992 Kaneko Company, Limited.[CR]A side scrolling beat'em up. 3 characters, one on a skateboard, one on a bike and one on rollerskates fight various enemies. Features a large amount of sampled voices and several rap songs.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main PCB # : ZO1DK-002[CR]ROM PCB # : ZO1DK-EXROM[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : (2x) OKI6295 (@ 12 Khz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]B.Rap Boys was released in June 1992.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. DJ Boy (1989)[CR]2. B.Rap Boys (1992)[CR]

game.name: Back Street Soccer (KRB-0031 PCB)
game.plot: Back Street Soccer (c) 1996 SunA Electronics Ind. Company, Limited.[CR]A Korean street soccer game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 3.579545 Mhz), (2x) Zilog Z80 (@ 5 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2151 (@ 3.579545 Mhz), (4x) DAC[CR]Players : 4[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Licensed to Unico for distribution.[CR]Back Street Soccer was SunA's first and only sports title. Characters' sprites are clearly ripped from a SNK Neo-Geo MVS game called "Street Hoop", a basketball game from Data East.[CR]The game's continue screen features pictures of world famous soccer players such as Diego Maradona, Jurgen Klinsmann and Roberto Baggio as backgrounds. The pictures also appeared when you complete the game.[CR]One of the music tracks in this game features voice samples from the console basketball game Jammit, such as 'Mama said knock you out!' and 'Time to bust yo grill, sucka!'.[CR]

It is known in Japan as "Dragonninja".[CR]This American version has a different ending sequence to that of the original Japanese version.[CR]A Bad Dudes vs. Dragonninja unit appears in the 1990 movie 'Robocop 2', and in the 1989 movie "Parenthood".[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo NES [EU] (1990) "Bad Dudes vs. Dragonninja [Model NES-55]" [CR]Nintendo NES [US] (July 1990) "Bad Dudes [Model NES-DU]" [CR]Nintendo Wii [US] (February 19, 2010) "Data East Arcade Classics [Model RVL-P-R26E]" [CR]Zeebo [MX] [BR] (July 27, 2010)[CR]* Computers : [CR]Amstrad CPC [EU] (1988) by Imagine [CR]Atari ST [EU] (1988) by Imagine [CR]Commodore Amiga [EU] (1988) "Bad Dudes vs. Dragon Ninja" [CR]Commodore 64 [US] [EU] (1988) [CR]PC [MS-DOS] [US] (1988) [CR]Commodore Amiga [US] (1989) "Bad Dudes" [CR]Atari ST [EU] (1989) by Hit Squad [CR]Sinclair ZX Spectrum (1989) [CR]Amstrad CPC [EU] (1989) by Ocean [CR]Apple II [US][CR]

game.name: Bagman
game.plot: Bagman (c) 1982 Valadon Automation [VA].[CR]The objective of the game is to maneuver Bagman through various mine shafts, picking up money bags and placing them in a wheelbarrow at the surface of the mine. The player must avoid pursuing guards, moving ore carts, and descending elevators. The player may temporarily stun the guards by striking them with a pickaxe or by dropping money bags on them when they are below the player on the same ladder. The player may move between the three screens which make up the level via shafts and on the surface.[CR]Bagman is played using one 4-way joystick and one action button. The joystick is also used to jump out of the ore cart. The Action Button is used to make the Bagman perform the following tasks:[CR]Pick up and drop money bags[CR]Pick up and drop pickaxe[CR]Grab and release the ceiling beam to avoid the ore cart (this can be done while carrying a money bag)[CR]Placing a money bag in the wheelbarrow[CR]Pick up and drop the wheelbarrow[CR]Points are scored for each horizontal step the player takes, for each money bag placed in the wheelbarrow, and for each guard stunned.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU: Zilog Z80 (@ 3.072 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips: General Instrument AY8910 (@ 1.5 Mhz), TMS5110 (@ 640 Khz) [speech][CR]Players: 2[CR]Control: 4-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons: 1[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Bagman was released in January 1982.[CR]Also licensed to Stern for US distribution (same month). [CR]The tune that plays at the start of the game is a sample from "Turkey in the Straw". [CR]Jerry McCloskey holds the official record for this game with 6840850 points on August 2, 1983. [CR]This game is known in France as "Le Bagnard" (translates from French as 'The Convict'). [CR]Bootlegs of this game run on the "Moon Cresta" & on the "Crazy Kong" hardware.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Bagman (1982)[CR]2. Super Bagman (1984)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Computers : [CR][US] [EU] Commodore C64 (1984) "Bagitman")[CR][US] [EU] Commodore C64 (1984) "Gilligan's Gold"[CR]

game.name: Bang Bang Ball (v1.05)
game.plot: Bang Bang Ball (c) 1996 Banpresto.[CR]Two skateboarding mouse dudes must face many strange puzzle challenges in order to rescue their girl who has been abducted by a nasty gang of cats! Features colourful graphics and interesting game mechanics. Care to have a ball of a good time? :)[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : YMF278B (@ 33.8688 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 320 x 224 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 60.00 Hz[CR]Palette Colors : 8192[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 1[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Good House.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Suzuki[CR]Game designer : Darma[CR]Directior : Ochi[CR]Character designer : Kunihiko Tashiro[CR]Graphics desiners : Mao, Shibata, Yoshimura, Rie[CR]Programmer : Machine Fire[CR]Sound designer : Efa[CR]Instruction card : Wyvern[CR]

game.name: Bang Bead
game.plot: Bang Bead (c) 2001 Visco Corp.[CR]A modern "pong"-like game with selectable characters.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0259[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Control Picture][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player (3 usables)[CR]=> [A] Return ball [B] Threat/Sliding occur [C] Miracle Swing (when maximum power)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Bang Bead was released in May 2001.[CR]This game runs on the Neo-Geo MVS (only in Europe) and was never released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Battle Flip Shot (1998)[CR]2. Bang Bead (2001)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Director : Tenzi[CR]Programmers : Bilgo Baggins (Code), Ana (Minarai)[CR]Graphic designers : Naka, Ber, Kan, Oka, Stickman (Swordman)[CR]

game.name: Baseball Stars 2
game.plot: Baseball Stars 2 (c) 1992 SNK.[CR]The sequel to SNK's popular baseball arcade game. Players can create leagues of up to 125 games (6 teams playing each other 25 times) and view statistics such as League Standings, Average, Home Runs, Runs Batted In, Earned Run Average, Wins and Saves. Players can fire players and upgrade them using the same 15-point system introduced in the original Baseball Stars.[CR]Players can select from one of 18 teams across 2 leagues - Exciting League (beginner) & Fighting League (expert) :[CR]Exciting League :[CR]* New York Monsters[CR]* Tokyo Ninjas[CR]* Napoli Angels[CR]* Taipei Hawks[CR]* Seoul Ivories[CR]* Sydney Griffons[CR]* Oaxaca Rockets[CR]* Barcelona Flames[CR]* London Lifeguards[CR]Fighting League :[CR]* USA Bisons[CR]* Japanese Samurais[CR]* Korean Dragoon[CR]* Italian Waves[CR]* Taiwan Dragons[CR]* Aussie Thunders[CR]* Mexican Typhoons[CR]* Spanish Galleons[CR]* British Knights[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID: NGM-041[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way[CR]Hitting: [A] Swing bat/Return to base, [B] Stolen base/Lead off, [C] Bunt, [D] Time out [CR]Fielding: [A] Pitch/Jump, [B] Base touch/Feint ball, [C] X, [D] Time out[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in April 1992.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Weaken Enemy Pitcher : To perform this trick, you need to get as close to the plate as you can. If the pitcher then hits you, tap Up twice on your joystick. Your hitter will then throw his bat to the floor, walk up to the mound and punch the pitcher, thus lowering his abilities. Using this tip will help mess up the pitching schedule for your opponent, and can lead to easy scoring opportunities off the tired pitchers.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Baseball Star - Mezase Sankanou [Model SFX-B9] (1989)[CR]2. Baseball Stars Professional [Model NGM-002] (1990)[CR]3. Baseball Stars 2 [Model NGM-041] (1992)[CR]4. Baseball Stars (1998, Neo Geo Pocket Color)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Planner : Pu-Ken 2020[CR]Programmers : To-Chan, Nakamura-Q[CR]Design chief : Miki, Y. game.name: Batsugun
game.plot: Batsugun (c) 1993 Toaplan.[CR]A vertically scrolling shoot'em up game. As is the standard with most arcade shooters, the player controls their ship with a joystick and two buttons. One button (Fire) shoots the main guns, and the other button (Bomb) releases a smart bomb that spreads huge energy balls all around the player's ship.[CR]As enemies are destroyed, the player gains experience points that are separate from the score. For every 288 experience points gained, the main gun will 'level up', becoming much stronger. This is analogous to experience points and leveling up in role playing games. The weapon can only level up twice, so after it has achieved its maximum level, 288 experience points will grant the player an extra bomb.[CR]The player can also grab P icons to increase the power of the current level gun. A maximum of five "P"s can be collected per experience level; getting more after this gives extra points instead.[CR]Collecting B icons increases the number of bombs, to a maximum of 7.[CR]Apart from destroying enemies, points can be gained from collecting golden V-shaped medals. After the level is finished, 3000 points are awarded for every small one, and 5000 points for every large one. If the player's ship is destroyed during a level, all medals collected are lost.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : TP-030[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2151 (@ 3.375 Mhz), OKI6295 (@ 24.242 Khz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> [A] Shot, [B] Bomb[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Batsugun was released in February 1993.[CR]BATSUGUN means 'Preeminence', 'Predominace' or 'By far the best'.[CR]BATSU means 'Dominant', 'Outstanding' or 'Excel'.[CR]GUN is originaly 'Group' or 'Brigade', but also means 'Common Level'.[CR]BATSU also means a cross (X) mark, so there's an X under the logo of Batsugun.[CR]Licensed to Taito for world distribution and to Unite Trading for Korea.[CR]This is the last shoot'em up and the first 'non-endless' game by Toaplan. A special version of Batsugun existed, originally it was only for the AOU show (Arcade Operators Union, an arcade game show held in Japan every year) and not for sale. After the Toaplan bankruptcy, the board started to appear on the second hand market.[CR]Heralded by some as the first 'maniac shooter', Batsugun involved employees who would go on to form and work at Cave and continue to work in this subgenre. Batsugun saw an evolution in the use of complex bullet and enemy patterns and player fire power and hit-box.[CR]The scoring trick on the fourth boss (destroy the two giant laser cannons, let the tanks appearing from the hangars fill the ramps and become red, bomb for 59,630 points a tank) was one source of inspiration for "Battle Garegga"'s gameplay.[CR]Pony Canyon released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Batsugun - PCCB-00151) on 18/03/1994.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Hidden Functions : If the 'Invulnerability dip switch' is enabled, you are invulnerable but you may also 'Pause' the game with P2 Start and restart with P1 Start.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Excecutive producer : Yuko Tataka[CR]Programmers : Suki! Suki! Kohchan No-Make, Sigue Hayasato, Tsuneki Ikeda (Ikeda In Naeba), Yoshitatsu Sakai (the 3rd)[CR]Graphic design : Yuko Tataka, Takeshi Kamamoto, Junya Inoue (Joker Jun)[CR]Characters designed by : Junya Inoue (Joker Jun)[CR]Musics composed by : Yoshitatsu Sakai (the 3rd)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn (1996) "Batsugun [Model T-20605G]"[CR]

game.name: Battle Arena Toshinden 2 (USA 951124)
game.plot: Battle Arena Toshinden 2 (c) 1995 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Battle Arena Toshinden 2 is a 3-D, weapons-based fighting game featuring a total of 15 different fighters - 11 main fighters, 2 hidden fighters and 2 bosses. Battles take place in a number of 3-D rendered arenas. Unlike most other 3-D fighters of the time - in which only the graphics are 3-D, with the actual fighting taking place on a 2-D plane - Battle Arena Toshinden features wholly 3-D gameplay that allows players to dive out of the path of their opponent's attacks.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Sony ZN-1 hardware[CR]Main CPU : SPU (@ 16.9344 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : SPU (@ 8 Mhz), Q-Sound (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 6[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Tamsoft, Battle Arena Toshinden 2 was released in November 1995 by Capcom.[CR]Sony Records released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Battle Arena Toshinden 2 Game Soundtrack - SRCL-3471) on April 21, 1996.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]The US version has the "Recycle It, Don't Trash It!" screen.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Battle Arena Toshinden (1994, PlayStation)[CR]2. Battle Arena Toshinden 2 (1995, PlayStation)[CR]3. Battle Arena Toshinden 2 Plus [Model SLPS-91006] (1996, PlayStation)[CR]4. Battle Arena Nitoshinden (1996, PlayStation)[CR]5. Battle Arena Toshinden Remix [Model 81029] (1996, Saturn)[CR]6. Battle Arena Toshinden URA - Ultimate Revenge Attack [Model 81054] (1996, Saturn)[CR]7. Battle Arena Toshinden 3 (1997, PlayStation)[CR]8. Battle Arena Toshinden 4 (1999, PlayStation)[CR]9. Battle Arena Toshinden (2009, Wii)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Director : Shintarou Nakaoka[CR]Assistant Director : Hideki Kobayashi[CR]Main Programmer : Hiroaki Furukawa [CR]Character Design : Miho Furukawa[CR]Sub Program : Etsuhiro Wada, Tooru Kawashima[CR]Motion Compose : Shinya Kusunoki, Hideki Matsumoto[CR]Motion Design : Toshihiro Ichino, Naotaka Suzuki, Hisashi Satou, Mizuki Muramatsu, Kou Ogura[CR]Background Design : Kanako Satou, Aki Kobayashi[CR]Effect Design : Kou Ogura[CR]Sound Design : Yasuhiro Nakano, Fumio Tanabe[CR]Sound Effect : Yasuhiro Nakano[CR]Adviser : Mitsutoshi Nomura, Masaru Nakagama, Toshimi Matsumoto, Kaori Akasaka[CR]Executive Producer : Toshiaki Ota[CR]Official Illustrator : Tsukasa Kotobuki[CR]Title Logo Design : Mitsuaki Hashimoto[CR]Story Plot : Chozi Yoshikawa[CR]Executive Producer : Nobuyuki Okude[CR]Producer : Takayuki Nakano[CR]Director : Takeshi Ikenoue[CR]Marketeer : Toshihiro Morioka, Hiroshi Takekawa[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (December 29, 1995) [Model SLPS-00200] [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (May 1996) [Model SLUS-00220] [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (June 1996) [Model SLPS-00232] [CR]* Computers : [CR]PC [MS Windows, CD-ROM] [US] (1997)[CR]

game.name: Battle Bakraid - Unlimited Version (USA) (Tue Jun 8 1999)
game.plot: Battle Bakraid (c) 1999 Eighting.[CR]The sequel to "Battle Garegga", an equally excellent vertically scrolling shoot 'em up game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : ET68-V99[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 16 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YMZ280B (@ 16.9344 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Vertical[CR]Video resolution : 240 x 320 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 60.00 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 2048[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in April 1999.[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'H!?'.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Battle Bakraid Original Soundtrack - SGCD-0008) on 19/06/1999.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]The 'Unlimited Version' (06/1999) has unlocking codes to gain access to five secret fighters and the special course.[CR][B]Scoring[/B][CR]Medals System : As long as you catch all medals of a wave, the increasing continues up to 10,000 points per medal. If you miss one, the next wave restarts at 100 point...[CR]1 : 100 points.[CR]2 : 200 points.[CR]3 : 300 points.[CR]4 : 400 points.[CR]5 : 500 points.[CR]6 : 600 points.[CR]7 : 700 points.[CR]8 : 800 points.[CR]9 : 900 points.[CR]10 : 1000 points.[CR]11 : 2000 points.[CR]12 : 3000 points.[CR]13 : 4000 points.[CR]14 : 5000 points.[CR]15 : 6000 points.[CR]16 : 7000 points.[CR]17 : 8000 points.[CR]18 : 9000 points.[CR]19 : 10,000 points.[CR]20 : 100,000 points - You can only trigger the 100k points medals when you have a multiplier active, and you can only continue to release 100k points medals if you continue to keep a multiplier going. Once you lose a multiplier, your medals revert back to 10k points medals.[CR]* Multiplier System : Bakraid features another scoring system that alters the amount of points gained from enemy destruction by modifying the base point gain from enemy destruction with a specially acquired incremental multiplier. The multiplier system is the more important of the two scoring systems as it is the system that can contribute to almost 80% of your total score, and is centric to the release of the special 100,000 points medals. However, the multiplier system is also the most difficult to get to grips with and exploit, as it requires a lot of pre-planning on the player's part with regards to stage and boss strategies in order to maximize potential point gains. The multiplier system in essence features an incremental multiplier that is gained by destroying LARGE enemies. You can continue to increment the multiplier up to a max of 64x, via this simple table (the number in brackets refers to the amount of large enemies destroyed to reach that multiplier stage) :[CR]2x (destroy 2)[CR]4x (3)[CR]8x (4)[CR]16x (5)[CR]32x (6)[CR]64x (7 and more)[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Ship Selection : at the ship select screen...[CR]1) To select a 'main shot power type' fighter, select your ship with A button.[CR]2) To select a 'Bomber power type', select your ship with B button.[CR]3) To select a 'Side shot power type', select your ship with C button.[CR]4) To select a 'Speed up type', select your ship with Start button.[CR]* Phase 2 : to unlock 3 more fighter planes, insert a coin and press Up(x2), Down(x2), Left, Right, Left, Right, A, B, Start.[CR]* Phase 3 : to unlock 2 more fighter planes, insert a coin and press Up(x2), Down(x2), Left, Right, Left, Right, B, A, Start (the entering of this code has to be finished before the counter passes 10).[CR]* Special Course : hold C button, insert a coin and press Up, Down, Up, Down Left, Right, Left, Right, B, A, Start and release C button.[CR]* Team Edit : insert a coin and press Up, Down, Up, Down Left, Right, Left, Right, A, B, Start (the entering of this code has to be started after the counter passes 10).[CR]* Stage Edit : start from the game mode selection screen, highlight the game mode of your choice and press A+B simultaneously.[CR]* Score Mode : to show up score calculations, start from anywhere in the game, hold C button and tap Joystick Up (to leave the score mode, re-enter the code).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Battle Garegga (1996)[CR]2. Battle Bakraid (1999)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Program 68000 Side : Shinobu Yagawa[CR]Program Z80 Side : Tatsuya Uemura[CR]Music composed by : Atsuhiro Motoyama[CR]Graphics: H. Tamai, N. Kaneko, F. Namie[CR]

game.name: Battle Rangers (World)
game.plot: Battle Rangers (c) 1988 Data East.[CR]In this shoot'em up, 2 lone commandos take on an entire army with guns, knives, fists and whatever else might be laying around.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : Hudson Soft HuC6280 (@ 7.159066 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Hudson Soft HuC6280 (@ 7.159066 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : YM2203 (@ 1.5 Mhz), OKI MSM5205 (@ 384 Khz), HuC6280 (@ 3.579545 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 256 x 232 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 60.00 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 512[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Even if the titlescreen of the game show a 1988 copyright, Battle Rangers was released to the public in February 1989.[CR]This game is known in US as "Bloody Wolf" and in Japan as "Narazumo Sentou Butai - Bloody Wolf".[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designer: Yoshiaki Honda[CR]Game programmers: Takaaki Inoue, Souichi Akiyama[CR]Graphic designers: Shinji Noda, Masanori Tokoro, Takahide Koizumi, Mix Man, Dot Man[CR]Sound team: Azusa Hara (AZUSA), Hiroaki Yoshida (MARO), Tatsuya, Hitomi, Shuji Segawa[CR]Hardware: Tomotaka Osada[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [EU] (June 29, 2007) [PA6P] TurboGrafx version[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [AU] (August 10, 2007) TurboGrafx version[CR]

game.name: Battletoads
game.plot: Battletoads (c) 1994 Electronic Arts[CR]The final, and most gruesome game in the Battletoads series. Unlike the home console games, the arcade version features more intense violence and a touch of adult humor (including a very unique way to hurt enemies twice your size...). Each toad features their own unique set of smash hits which can be executed to finish off the enemies - such as the Drilla Killa, the Battletoad 'Butt and the Big Bad Boot.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : TMS34020 (@ 10 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : BSMT2000 (@ 24 Mhz)[CR]Players : 3[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in December 1994.[CR]Licensed from Rare Coin-it Games.[CR]The last game of the critically-acclaimed series that was originally released for the Nintendo NES in 1991. This is a unique game which was never ported to consoles.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Battletoads (1991, Nintendo NES)[CR]2. Battletoads and Double Dragon (1993, Nintendo NES)[CR]3. Battletoads in Battlemaniacs (1993, Nintendo Super NES)[CR]4. Battletoads in Ragnarok's World (1993, Nintendo Game Boy)[CR]5. Battletoads (1994)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Main program : Chris Sutherland[CR]Additional programming : Mark Wilson[CR]Game design : Gregg Mayles[CR]Additional design : Kevin Bayliss, Chris Sutherland[CR]Main character artist : Kevin Bayliss[CR]Additional character artists : Keri Gunn, Gregg Mayles, Steve Mayles, Chris Peil[CR]Main background artist : Kevin Bayliss[CR]Additional background artists : Gregg Mayles, Steve Mayles, Chris Peil, Dean Smith[CR]3-D Computer models : Kevin Bayliss[CR]Hardware concept : Chris Stamper[CR]Hardware design and construction : Pete Cox, Chris Stamper[CR]Audio software : Chris Sutherland[CR]Music and sound effects : Dave Wise[CR]Additional sound effects : Gregg Mayles, Chris Sutherland[CR]Sound effect sampling : Dave Wise[CR]Vocal effects : Kevin Bayliss, Mark Betteridge, Simon Farmer, Chris Peil, John Stamper, Louise Stamper, Chris Sutherland[CR]Quality assurance : Simon Farmer, Gary Richards, Huw Ward[CR]Original battletoads concept : Tim Stamper[CR]Original battletoads design : Kevin Bayliss, Mark Betteridge, Tim Stamper[CR]Produced by : Chris Stamper, Tim Stamper[CR]
