game.name: Truxton / Tatsujin
game.plot: Tatsujin (c) 1988 Taito Corp.[CR]Taking place somewhere in the near future of space travel, an alien armada is invading the player's home planet aboard 5 gargantuan asteroids. After surviving an attack on the player's cargo barge, players board and pilot one remaining fighter and challenge the aliens in a desperate attempt to quell the alien invasion and divert their asteroid fortresses in the process.[CR]Tatsujin is a vertical scrolling shooter arcade game, featuring 8 levels with non-stop action and 5 bosses.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : TP-013B[CR]Prom Stickers : B65[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 10 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 3.5 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : YM3812 (@ 3.5 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Tatsujin was released in October 1988 in Japan.[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Master'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as Truxton.[CR]Polystar released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Tatsujin : Toaplan Game Music Scene One - H24X-10005) on 25/06/1989.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Hidden Functions : If the 'Invulnerability dip switch' is enabled, you are invulnerable but you may also 'Pause' the game with P2 Start and restart with P1 Start.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Tatsujin [TP-013B] (1988)[CR]2. Tatsujin Oh [TP-024] (1992)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Developed by Toaplan.[CR]Staff : Lee Ota[CR]Music composed by : Masahiro Yuge[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Mega Drive (1989) "Tatsujin [Model G-4020]"[CR]NEC PC-Engine (1992) "Tatsujin [Model TP-04022]"[CR]FM Towns Marty "Tatsujin"[CR]

game.name: Tumble Pop (World)
game.plot: Tumble Pop (c) 1991 Data East Corporation.[CR]Tumble Pop is a platform game for one or two players in which the aim is to clear each level of enemies by sucking them into - then ejecting them from - a portable vacuum-cleaner. [CR]Holding down the fire button sucks the enemies into the cleaner, releasing the button causes them to be expelled back out. Ejected enemies act as projectiles that can damage and kill any other on-screen enemies that they collide with. All enemies must be killed before players can progress to the next stage. [CR]Throughout the game, letters of the alphabet randomly appear in bubbles. These can be collected to eventually spell the word "TUMBLEPOP". Once this has been achieved players are transported to a time-limited bonus level, giving them the opportunity to earn bonus points and extra lives. [CR]If players take too long to finish a stage, a Dracula-like enemy appears. If it touches a player before all enemies have been eliminated, a life is lost. This also applies to the Boss levels. [CR]The game feature ten stages, with the first eight set in different parts of the World and the final two set in Outer Space. Each stage has its own themed enemies and level bosses and players can choose to start the game on any of the eight World-based stages. The levels and enemies are: [CR]*Moscow: Set at the Moscow-state circus, enemies are clowns, invisible conjurers and fire spitters. The boss is a giant clown hanging from helium balloons who juggles bombs. [CR]*Egypt: Set near the pyramids and Sphinx at Giza, enemies include fire spitters and mummies. The boss is a giant genie who spits fireballs. [CR]*Paris: Set near the Arc de Triomphe, all of the enemies are robots. The boss is a large flying robot that sends out flying hands. [CR]*New York City: Set near the Statue of Liberty and World Trade Center, the enemies are pumpkin-headed zombies and octopuses. The boss is a giant octopus. [CR]*Rio de Janeiro: Set near the statue of Christ the Redeemer, enemies are fire monsters. The boss is a fire dragon. [CR]*Antarctica: Populated by snowmen, snowmen armed with shovels and hairy yeti-like monsters. The boss is a giant snowman wearing a bucket on its head. [CR]*Australia. Enemies are carnivorous plants, cavemen and mud men. The boss is a giant two-headed carnivorous plant. [CR]*Japan: Set at Mount Fuji, enemies are yureis, kappas and skeletons. The boss is a giant pile of daruma dolls. [CR]*Outer Space: Enemies are grey aliens and spacemen with blaster guns. The boss is a flying robot. [CR]*The Moon: All bosses from the previous worlds must be fought again. The game's final boss is a cyborg mad scientist controlling a giant robot.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : MAP[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 14 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Hudson Soft HuC6280 (@ 4.0275 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2151 (@ 3.58 Mhz), OKI6295 (@ 6.06 Khz)[CR]Screen Orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video Resolution : 319 x 240 Pixels[CR]Screen Refresh : 58.00 Hz [CR]Palette Colors : 1024[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> Fire, Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Tumble Pop was released in November 1991.[CR]Tumble Pop is the first of a trilogy of similar games produced by Data East, all with the same gameplay but at least with just few differences : a year after Tumble Pop, in 1992 Data East released "Diet Go Go", similar to Tumble Pop in the game mechanics, but the vacuum cleaner are discarded with special fruits released by the players for pump up the enemies; at this point the enemy will fly up to the screen, and the player spin him against the other enemies simply by touching him while he's flying. In 1994 is released '"Joe & Mac Returns", still similar to Tumble Pop, but the players must first dizzy the enemies with their canes, then capturing them and at least throw against the other enemies. [CR]There are several references with other Data East games with the enemies of Tumble Pop :[CR]* First of all, the fat Arabian-type guy spitting flames from his mouth is, naturally, a retrieval of the good old Karnov, even if it's not too identical to the original in the aesthetics (the eating-fire guy of Tumblepop doesn't have the thin mustache, and even the eyes are different). This enemy appears in the stage of Russia, Egypt and Brazil.[CR]* In the Australia stage, the cavemen and carnivorous plants are the same as those appearing in Caveman Ninja. The end level boss is identical to the Giant Carnivorous Plant of the second stage, still on Caveman Ninja.[CR]* The end level boss of Brazil stage (the fire dragon) is almost identical to the mid boss of the second stage of Chelnov - Atomic Runner (the Giant Dog with iron mask). Some of his patterns are also similar to another boss in Caveman Ninja.[CR]* The 'pain scream' of some bosses was copied from the Dinosaurs growl of Caveman Ninja.[CR]* In the Space stages, one enemy (the alien with white suit and helmet) is exactly identical to Chelnov. Even his fire attacks are identical to one of the power ups of the game Chelnov - Atomic Runner.[CR]In the Brazil stage, in the first scheme there are five special letters hidden (See TIPS AND TRICKS section to learn more about the special letters) that joined together forms the name SENNA,: clearly an homage to the late Brazilian F1 world champion Ayrton Senna.[CR]In 1994 an anonymous Korean software house, Dong Gue La Mi Ltd., made a hack version of this game, named "Pang Pang". This game is simply awful, with all the backgrounds of the original game changed to the backgrounds of Super Pang. Also, you can't catch the enemies with the vacuum cleaner, but you can catch them inside some bubbles, exactly like in Bubble Bobble. The main character of the game controlled by the player is a horrible rip-off of the hero of Tumble Pop.[CR]The final boss and villain of the game, Mad Doctor, appears also in "Diet Go Go" and "Spin Masters", both still developed by Data East.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Wolf Fang, Tumble Pop - PCCB-00084) on March 21, 1992.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Bootlegs don't use the HuC6280 @ 4.0275 Mhz :-)[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]To eliminate an enemy, the simple way is to catch him with the vacuum cleaner, and then throw him away before he gets out by himself and kills you. You can also throw an enemy against other one, and especially catch more enemies at a time, in order to create a real "avalanche" that will run over the others. The basic strategy for every scheme is to catch as many enemies as possible, and then throw them against the other enemies, so you can clean up the whole screen and accumulate many points.[CR]Every enemy killed will still release an item that gives you bonus points (coins, gems, diamonds, etc.).[CR]For catch an enemy, press the FIRE button and hold it while the enemy will be sucked inside the vacuum cleaner. However, there is a simple trick to catch them faster, press the fire button ONCE against the enemy, or press the fire button and then turn back to him fast; the enemy will get dizzy for a few seconds. Now, just press again the fire button to immediately suck him inside the vacuum cleaner. Now keep the fire button pressed as long as you don't want to drop him. REMEMBER: You can't hold enemies in your vacuum cleaner for more than 4-5 seconds.[CR]The enemies generally walk around on the screen and jump to different platforms. Especially, there are some kinds of enemies that can turn themselves into a type of tornado before going up or down to the next platform; in this moment these enemies are invincible, you can't catch them and also the 'tornado form' will block eventually enemies that you've thrown against them.[CR]When you fight a boss, you must defeat him by catching the weapons or enemies that he will drop and then throw these against him. If you catch more than three enemies, you'll give more damage to the boss.[CR]In some levels, there are some types of jars, that will release constantly new enemies. The form of these jars changes with the stage's background, but despite this these are all identical to each other. You need to hit these jars throwing enemies against them for two or three times to destroy them. After being destroyed, the jars will release some gems. Sometimes there are two jars in the same level.[CR]You can catch enemies even through walls. This is a great advantage to you, especially against those enemies that can shoot from far distances or when you're near too busy platforms.[CR]There are several bonus items and power ups hidden all over the screen. At the beginning those are not visible; you must first catch some enemies and then throw them in the open space of the level, and especially near the corner where the power-ups are often frequent.[CR]Dropping a single enemy is not effective to discover all the bonuses of a level: the best way is to catch three or more enemies and then throw them in an empty space, which makes them roll over the whole screen and then revealing the bonuses.[CR]The power ups are generally placed in the various corners at the left or right of the screen, and occasionally in the central platforms of the screen. Keep this in mind if you are actually looking for a power up.[CR]There are several power ups :[CR]"Skate" : make the player's character movements faster.[CR]"Star" : Give to the player a barrier that makes him invincible for some time and kill enemies by simple contact.[CR]"Laser Pistol" : Turn your vacuum cleaner in a laser pistol, that kills all the enemies and jars instantly.[CR]"Package ?" : This will recall a large vacuum cleaner above the screen that will clean up the whole screen of every enemy and bonus item: however, the points for the bonus and enemies are still added to the player's score, but you'll not take the benefit of the power ups.[CR]"Tumblepop's Guy" : this is the classical 1UP item, which gives you an extra life. Only available in the bonus stage.[CR]Special letters : these are special items that will appear on screen like the other bonus items. At the bottom of the screen there is the word TUMBLE POP written with the letters placed inside blue balls. You must collect the letters that make the word TUMBLE POP. Once you've completed it, you'll be teleported into a bonus stage where you can collect any type of money and gems and an extra life, before time runs out. If you made it to collect all the items, the time left will become bonus points. After the bonus stage is completed, you'll be teleported into the next level. There are some letters that don't belong to the word TUMBLE POP, which only count as extra points.[CR]In the final stage, before you fight against the final boss (Mad Doctor), you'll fight against the previous bosses. This is the only time that you can find power ups in a boss fight.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Makoto Kikuchi[CR]Programmers : Hidemi Hamada, Kei Ichikawa, M. Sano[CR]Designers : Atsushi Takahashi, Ryohey Hirakata, Touma Arakawa, Sanomi Kiyota, Chie Kitahara, Oguri, Noriyuki Morita, Yasuko Kurohiji, Hiroshi Tada[CR]Sound : Tomoyoshi Sato (Tom Sato), Seila, Tatsuya Kiuchi (Mr.K)[CR]Hardware : T. Kanayama[CR]Special Thanks : Masanori Tokoro, Honda Yoshiaki, Tomoo Adachi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Nintendo Game Boy [JP] (November 20, 1992) "Tumble Pop [Model DMG-T6J]" [CR]Nintendo Game Boy [US] (March 1993) "Tumble Pop [Model DMG-T6]" [CR]Nintendo 3DS [Virtual Console] [JP] (April 12, 2012) Game Boy version [CR]Nintendo 3DS [Virtual Console] [EU] [AU] (June 7, 2012) Game Boy version [CR]Nintendo 3DS [Virtual Console] [US] (July 19, 2012) Game Boy version[CR]

game.name: Tutankham
game.plot: Tutankham (c) 1982 Konami.[CR]Inside King Tut's tomb are treasures beyond your wildest dreams. They can be yours... if you dare to take them. Supernatural creatures roam the mazes of the tomb guarding the treasures at all costs. Your only defenses against them are your laser gun... and your wits. Blast away, snatch the loot, escape through secret passageway before it's too late! And when you see a key, take that, too. It will unlock the door to the next chamber and the next adventure. Enter King Tut's tomb and see what awaits you... if you dare.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : GX350[CR]Main CPU : Motorola M6809 (@ 1.5 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ ~1.79 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : (2x) General Instrument AY8910 (@ ~1.79 Mhz), (6x) RC (@ ~1.79 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 4-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Tutankham was released in June 1982.[CR]The game was originally to be called 'Tutankhamon'. However, when programmers decided to change the monitor position from horizontal to vertical, they had to cut the -ON suffix from 'Tutankhamon' to make the title fit the screen width.[CR]Licensed to Stern for manufacture and distribution in USA as "Tutankham".[CR][B]Scoring[/B][CR]Killing a Snake : 20 points.[CR]Killing a Monster : 40 points.[CR]Killing a Bat : 60 points.[CR]Collecting a Ring : Mystery Score (From 500 points).[CR]Collecting a Lantern : Mystery Score (Up to 4,000 points).[CR]Collecting a key : 500 points.[CR]Opening a door : 1,000 points.[CR]Bonus points are awarded at the end of each level for the time remaining.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Flash bombs can only be used once per level, and remember you only have 3 available for the whole game. Use them sparingly, preferably only in a life-threatening situation.[CR]* You can sit in a safe place close to a monster generator and simply pick the monsters off as they appear. Most monsters follow a set pattern of movement so it is quite easy to predict which way they will turn and wait in a place where it is easy to kill them as they appear in front or behind you. Remember to watch the timer though![CR]* The lanterns and rings are quite often a deadly diversion as they are sometimes placed in dead end vertical passages. Assess the risks carefully before collecting them.[CR]* Be careful when entering vertical tunnels as you cannot shoot monsters on the other side until they are level with you in a horizontal direction.[CR]* A carefully timed shot can kill a monster in a vertical tunnel, but only when fired exactly when the monster moves into the square in which you are stood.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Programmed by : H. Tanigaki[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Casio PV-1000[CR]Nintendo DS [JP] (March 15, 2007) "Konami Arcade Collection [Model NTR-P-ASKJ (RY039-J1)]" [CR]Nintendo DS [EU] (October 26, 2007) "Konami Arcade Classics [Model NTR-P-ACXP]" [CR]Nintendo DS [AU] (October 29, 2007) "Konami Arcade Classics" [CR]Nintendo DS [JP] (October 29, 2009) "Konami Arcade Collection [Konami Dendou Selection] [Model NTR-ASKJ-JPN-1 (RY039-J4)]" [CR]* Computers :[CR]Sinclair ZX Spectrum [EU] (1984)[CR]* Others :[CR]LCD handheld game : released by Konami.[CR]VFD handheld game (1983) : released by Bandai.[CR]

game.name: Twin Bee Yahhoo! (ver JAA)
game.plot: Twin Bee Yahhoo! Fushigi no Kuni de Dai Abare!! (c) 1995 Konami.[CR]Twin Bee Yahho! differs from Detana!! TwinBee in that the player can adjust their playing style before starting the game to suit their preference. The player begins by choosing between three difficulty settings: Practice, Normal, and Special. Practice course is the game's easiest setting and lasts only three stages, whereas the Special course is the hardest setting and is recommended to expert players. The player will then select between four different charged shots. The regular Charge Shot from Detana! TwinBee is selectable, along with a Charge Punch, a Charge Split (which will cause the player's ship to shoot duplicates of itself), and a Charge Explosion that fires at eight directions at the same time. The player will then choose between two control styles: one which fires the gun with one button and drops bombs with the second, while the other style shoots and drops bomb at the same time with a single button (either button can be used).[CR]Like in previous Twin Bee games, there are two kinds of power-ups: bell power-ups obtained from the sky and land power-ups that can be retrieved from destroy ground enemies. The bells can be changed to up to six colors this time (yellow, blue, white, green, red, and pink), each with a unique attribute. GwinBee returns as well as a power-up item, along with the twin attacks that can be performed with GwinBee or another player.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Konami GX hardware[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68EC020[CR]Sound CPU : Motorola 68000[CR]Sound Chips : (2x) K054539[CR]Players : 4[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Twin Bee Yahhoo! was released in April 1995.[CR]The subtitle of this game translates from Japanese as 'Uproar In A Mysterious Land'.[CR]The J-Pop song played in attract mode (make sure that get it via the dipswitches) is called 'Bokura no Suteki' and is sung by Mariko Kouda. Here are the Japanese lyrics :[CR]kanashimi no mori o, sama you kimi wa -[CR]futo sora o mite, uchuu o omou -[CR]ikutsumono ginga -[CR]IMEEJI shita, sono mune ni -[CR]umareru yuuki -[CR]yume o mite, aruki daseru no wa -[CR]bokura no SUTEKI sa, kimi to -[CR]mirai e yukou -[CR]soba ni ite, sasae au koto wa -[CR]inochi no SUTEKI no hitotsu -[CR]kodoku ni ochinaide.[CR]Here is the translated version :[CR]You are wandering about the sorrowful woods -[CR]See the sudden skies, think about outer space -[CR]A lot of Galaxies -[CR]On that imagined chest -[CR]The courage to be born -[CR]See the dreams and we can begin to walk -[CR]You are lovely to us -[CR]Going to the future -[CR]It's in the side and supports each other -[CR]The one lovely life -[CR]Don't fall alone.[CR]King Records released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Twin Bee Yahhoo! Original Game Soundtrack - KICA-7681) on June 7, 1995.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Twin Bee [Model GX412] (1985, Arcade)[CR]2. Moero TwinBee - Cinnamon Hakase wo Sukue! [Model KDS-TIN] (1986, Famicom Disk System)[CR]3. Twin Bee 3 - Poko Poko Dai Maou [Model KON-RC841] (1989, Famicom)[CR]4. TwinBee da!! [Model DMG-TDJ] (1990, Game Boy)[CR]5. Detana!! Twin Bee (1991, Arcade)[CR]6. Pop'n TwinBee [Model SHVC-PT] (1993, Super Famicom)[CR]7. Twin Bee Yahhoo! Fushigi no Kuni de Dai Abare!! (1995, Arcade)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (September 29, 1995) "Detana Twinbee Yahoo! Deluxe Pack [Model T-9505G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (September 29, 1995) "Detana TwinBee Yahoo! Deluxe Pack [Model SLPS-00100]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (December 11, 1997) "Detana TwinBee Yahoo! Deluxe Pack [PlayStation the Best] [Model SLPM-86054]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (November 20, 2003) "Detana TwinBee Yahoo! Deluxe Pack [PSOne Books] [Model SLPM-87322 (VX012-J4)]" [CR]Sony PSP [JP] (January 25, 2007) "Twin Bee Portable [Model ULJM-05221 (VP032-J1]" [CR]Sony PSP [JP] (March 13, 2008) "Twin Bee Portable [Konami the Best] [Model ULJM-05323]"[CR]

game.name: Twin Cobra (World)
game.plot: Twin Cobra (c) 1987 Taito Corp.[CR]Export version. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese version release; "Kyuukyoku Tiger [TP-011]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : TP-011[CR]Prom Sticker : B30[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Toaplan. Twin Cobra was released in October 1987.[CR]Licensed to Romstar for US distribution (November 1988).[CR]This game is known in Japan as "Kyuukyoku Tiger [TP-011]".[CR]Differences between Twin Cobra (TC) and Kyukyoku Tiger (KT) :[CR]* TC supports two simultaneous players.[CR]* KT supports two players, but only one at a time. For this reason, it also supports Table Top cabinets.[CR]* TC stores 3 characters for high scores.[CR]* KT stores 6 characters for high scores.[CR]* TC heros are Red and Blue for player 1 and 2 respectively.[CR]* KT heros are grey for both players.[CR]* TC dead remains of ground tanks are circular.[CR]* KT dead remains of ground tanks always vary in shape.[CR]* TC continues new hero and continued game at current position.[CR]* KT continues new hero and continued game at predefined positions. After dying and your new hero appears, if you do not travel more than your helicopter length forward, you are penalised and moved back further when your next hero appears. Due to this difference in continue sequence, KT is MUCH harder, challenging and nearly impossible to complete ![CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Twin Cobra [TP-011] (1987)[CR]2. Twin Cobra II (1995)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo NES [US] (January 1990) [Model NES-QT][CR]Sega Genesis [US] (1991) [CR]Sega Mega Drive [BR] (1991, "Desert Attack Helicopter" - Tec Toy) [CR]* Computers :[CR]Commodore C64 (1988)[CR]

game.name: Twin Eagle - Revenge Joe's Brother
game.plot: Twin Eagle - Revenge Joe's Brother (c) 1988 Seta.[CR]A vertical shoot-em-up that places the player's helicopter against multiple attacking targets in the air, sea, and land. Collecting the weapon and speed power-ups throughout the game is vital since the gameplay is quite difficult.[CR]The object of the game, which is not explained further, is to avenge Joe's brother - which is probably not assumed to be the player, but presumably a friend of the player who lost his brother to the enemy. (It uses bad English grammar on the subtitle of the screen, using "revenge" as a verb, as apposed to "avenge". That being said, it's a pretty tight game otherwise.) To do so, you must destroy the fortress on the very last level. When you start the game and it scrolls onto the starting screen, the background contains the different levels that you must survive. The starting position of the various enemies does not vary from game to game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Board Number : M6100326A[CR]Prom Stickers : UA2[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 8 Mhz), M65C02 (@ 1 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : X1-010 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> [A] Shoot, [B] Bomb[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Twin Eagle was released in April 1988 in Japan by Taito.[CR]Licensed to Romstar for US distribution.[CR]The entire sound production was done by a freelancer sound team, Goblin Sound. A soundtrack CD was released by Seta in 1989 as "Twin Eagle and Real Majhong 3".[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Power-up items :[CR]1) M = Shot Multiplier[CR]2) L = Slightly increased shot length[CR]3) S = Slightly increased helicopter maneuverability[CR]4) B = Extra bomb[CR]5) Although it is ultra-rare, a floating icon can appear (instead of a balloon) which contains a full multi-shot powerup.[CR]* Completely destroying the bunkers before shooting any of the men behind them almost always yields a shot-multiplier power-up. One can regularly have the maximum number of shot multipliers by the end of the first level by using this trick. Power-ups seem to appear more frequently if you stay with your guns and do not pick up a missile power-up. Fire as often as you can when you are using the guns, and keep firing. Once you have maxed out your shot multiplier, it is good to start picking up missiles. Part of the trick to playing the game is to scroll the screen from side to side and to pick off the enemies that are placed on opposite sides to harass you.[CR]* By learning the pattern of when and where enemies appear, you can neutralize them before they can do you any harm. This is especially true with hitting the small helicopters as they come on screen, and nuking the screen just before the guided missile truck. It is best to use the screen nuke when your helicopter is positioned at the very bottom of the screen. Otherwise, it may only be partially effective.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Twin Eagle - Revenge Joe's Brother (1988)[CR]2. Twin Eagle II - The Rescue Mission (1994)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Produced by : Jun Fujimoto[CR]Game designed by : MTY, Yam[CR]Game programmed by : MTY[CR]Game sub programmed by : Kazuaki Nakanishi[CR]System programmed by : H. Kobayashi, K. Yoshii[CR]Graphic designed by : Sachiko[CR]Character designers : K. Sato, A. Kumura, M. Kasajima, M. Takeda[CR]Music direction by Goblin Sound.[CR]Music composers : Zero Yotsumoto, T. Suzuki, Conrad T. Kozawa[CR]Music performers : T. Suzuki, Zero Yotsumoto, Coke Taguchi, T. Tanno, S. Tsutsui[CR]Sound edited by : T. Suzuki, T. Hasegawa[CR]Allugataya system : T. Hasegawa, T. Suzuki, K. Okuda[CR]Game advised by : J. Narita[CR]Graphic editer designed by : M. Watanabe[CR]68K Chan : K. Ishikawa[CR]Board designed by : Nobuyuki Nonaka[CR]Pcm 16 : K. Oiyama[CR]Vdc : T. Iwata, K. Oiyama[CR]Vrc : Nobuyuki Nonaka[CR]Sound filter : Shyachou, M. Tanaka[CR]Eigiyou : T. Ishikawa, Y. Ota[CR]Jimu : T. Watanabe, T. Hiroi, K. Komura, M. Tanaka[CR]Koubai : M. Harada, M. Iwata[CR]Koumu : Y. Ikegai[CR]Seizou : A. Aranaga, T. Sasho, K. Tominaga[CR]Character model maked by : M. Takeda, Kazuaki Nakanishi, S. Tanaka[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR][US] Nintendo NES (1989) "Twin Eagle - Revenge Joe's Brother [Model NES-2E-USA]"[CR][JP] Nintendo Famicom (1991) "Twin Eagle - Revenge Joe's Brother [Model VIS-2E]"[CR]

game.name: Twin Eagle II - The Rescue Mission
game.description: Twin Eagle II - The Rescue Mission
game.title_clean: Twin Eagle II - The Rescue Mission
game.plot: Twin Eagle II - The Rescue Mission (c) 1994 Seta Company, Limited.[CR]Twin Eagle II is a vertical scrolling shooter where one or two players pilot heavily armed helicopters through three stages with three areas each.[CR]At the start of each stage, the players select their path of attack through the three areas. Areas with ground level enemies and targets are presented in a 3/4 isometric view, while areas with no ground targets feature scrolling landscape images. Players use their guns to attack flying enemy aircraft and bombs to attack ground targets such as tanks, rocket launchers and high-rise skyscrapers. If things get too hairy, the player can use a missile barrage to clear the screen of enemies and enemy firepower. Destroying some buildings reveal primary colored trucks which drop weapon power-ups and point items when destroyed. Each area features a boss at the end, which must be destroyed to advance past the area. The final stage features one additional boss before the end of the game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Seta SSV system[CR]Main CPU : V60 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : ES5506 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Twin Eagle II was released in February 1994.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Twin Eagle - Revenge Joe's Brother (1988)[CR]2. Twin Eagle II - The Rescue Mission (1994)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Programmers : Noboru Harada, Takashi Kitabayashi[CR]Graphics designers : Kohzoh Igarashi, Katutoshi Hiruta, Shingo Aoyama[CR]CG Designer : Yasuhiko Kikuchi[CR]Hardware engineer : Masahiro Yamaguchi[CR]Soundtrack : Opus Corp.[CR]Executive producer : Jun Fujimoto[CR]

game.name: Twin Hawk (World)
game.plot: Twin Hawk (c) 1989 Taito.[CR]A vertically scrolling shoot'em up.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Taito X System hardware[CR]Prom Stickers : B87[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 8 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2151 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in June 1989.[CR]Developed by Toaplan. Even if developed by this famous shoot'em up company, Twin Hawk was not good game and it was a flop. [CR]This game is known in Japan as "Dai Sen Puu".[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]There are several differences between Twin Hawk and its Japanese version "Dai Sen Puu" :[CR]* Twin Hawk supports two simultaneous players.[CR]* Dai Sen Puu supports two players, but only one at a time. Because of this, it also supports Cocktail cabinets.[CR]* In Twin Hawk, both planes are purple and pink for player 1 and 2 respectively.[CR]* In Dai Sen Puu, the planes are green for both players.[CR]* In Twin Hawk, when you die, you continue the game at current position.[CR]* In Dai Sen Puu, when you die, you continue the game at predefined positions. This makes the game much more difficult to complete.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Sound Composer: Osamu Oota[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Mega Drive (1990)[CR]

game.name: Twinkle Star Sprites
game.plot: Twinkle Star Sprites (c) 1997 SNK.[CR]Twinkle Star Sprites is a competitive scrolling shooter game originally created by ADK. It was ADK's last production for the Neo-Geo platform. The gameplay, which can be characterized as a combination of a fixed shooter and a versus puzzle game, uses combinations of shots, as well as timed power-ups to attempt to damage the opponent. These attacks also serve as counters to the opponent's attack.[CR]An interesting & highly cute hybrid between a Vs style puzzle game & an overhead shooter, players may choose to play the Story Mode in order to see the misadventures of Load Ran & her faithful yet somewhat annoying Rabbicat as they try to find the Magical Twinkle Star & save their world from the evil Mevious & his henchmen. The other option is to play the Free Character Mode in which you are able to pick any character (see codes under Tips and Tricks) to play the game and see their very own comical ending. A second player may challenge you at any time.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0224[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2b[A] Shoot/Use attack-stopper, [B] Bomb[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Twinkle Star Sprites was released in January 1997.[CR]The game's concept seems to be a funny parody of the Sailor Moon manga, however the game's comic relief 'Rabbicat' seems to be a parody of Tenchi Muyo's very own cute mascot & comic relief 'Ryo-Oh-Ki' the cabbit.[CR]Load Ran & Sprites feature different endings in the Free Character Mode, these endings are completely different to the one seen in the Story Mode.[CR]In the story mode, Mevious will either taunt or praise you if continues have been used during your game or not![CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Twinkle Star Sprites - PCCB-00247) on 21/02/1997.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]There are two types of standard attacks: a normal shot and a charge-up shot. Each character starts with two bombs which enables him in the event of desperate plight, to clean with the screen while briefly acquiring a state of invincibility. The two players' playfields are separated by a vertical bar, each one having its own independent of the other. Series of enemies arrive from the top of the screen. The player is to successfully destroy them in chains (combos), which will send one or more fireball projectiles to the screen of his adversary (Normal Attack). Shooting at Normal Attacks several times reflects them back as glowing Reverse Attacks. If Reverse Attacks are reflected again, a number of powerful counterattacks in the shape of one or more indestructible enemies appear (Extra Attack). Reflecting many Reverse Attacks at once can instead summon a boss (Boss Attack).[CR]* The Extra Attacks and the Boss Attack vary from one character to another.[CR]* The power gauge fills as the player destroys enemies up to three levels. By holding down the fire button and releasing when a certain level is reached, the player can launch a character-specific charge shot to assist the player in clearing enemies from his screen. At Level 1, the charge shot is launched. At Level 2, the charge shot and three Extra Attacks against the opponent are launched. At Level 3 (Max Level), the charge shot and a Boss Attack are launched. Firing charge shots at Level 2 and above will decrease the power gauge.[CR]* 30–40 seconds into a round, a blue orb appears among a chain of enemies. If this orb is destroyed in a chain, the player achieves Fever status for the next several seconds. Chains created during Fever generate faster and more plentiful Normal Attacks per enemy destroyed, which can prove to be very dangerous to the opponent if large chains are made.[CR]* Both players are given five life points at the start of a round.[CR]* Colliding into an enemy costs 1 life point, but the player cannot be killed this way; if a player has one life point left, he will be left with one half of a life point. When this happens, his character is stunned for a short while and is reduced in speed and attack power for several seconds after recovery, all the while left more vulnerable to opponent attacks.[CR]* Getting hit by a Normal Attack, Reverse Attack, Extra Attack or the projectiles from a Boss cost 3 life points.[CR] [CR]* The match is over when a player loses all his life points.[CR]* When a player takes damage, his opponent recovers life points equal to half of the damage taken.[CR]* If a round lasts longer than 100 seconds or the player does not fire a shot for more than 30 seconds, a Death enemy appears. If a player is hit by this enemy, he will lose immediately (Death Attack). The Death can be destroyed as any other enemy, but always comes back, harder to kill. Additionally, if a player is successful in volleying the "death" character over to his opponent's side, and the death character touches the opponent, the opponent dies instantly. This is a possible, though difficult, way to win. This, of course, would require the player to be skilled enough to avoid obstacles and not fire for more than 30 seconds.[CR]* Special Codes:[CR]Play As Sprites : At the character select screen, put the selector on Ran and press Up(x4), A.[CR]Play As Memory : At the character select screen, put the selector on Ran and press Down(x4), A.[CR]Play As Mevious : At the character select screen, put the selector on Griffon and press Up(x4), A.[CR]Play As Dark Ran : At the character select screen, put the selector on Griffon and press Down(x4), A.[CR]* After the Game Over screen, Load Ran & Rabbicat rate your performance and either praise you or give you advice to improve your score, get a very high score (1,000.000 and above) in order to attain the highest rating and make Load Ran blush.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Developed by ADK.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (Feb.1997) "Twinkle Star Sprites [Model ADCD-013]"[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (Dec.1997) "Twinkle Star Sprites [Model T-37301G]"[CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (Mar.2000) "Twinkle Star Sprites [Model T-3103M]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (Dec.2008) "ADK Tamashii [Model SLPS-25906]"[CR]

game.name: U.N. Squadron (USA)
game.plot: U.N. Squadron (c) 1989 Capcom USA, Incorporated.[CR]North American release. For more information on this game itself, refer to the original Japanese entry; "Area 88 [B-Board 88622B-3]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Capcom Play System Hardware (CP-S)[CR]B-Board: 89624B-2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]U.N. Squadron was released in August 1989 in North America by Capcom USA. It is known in Japan as "Area 88".[CR]In this version, the special mission is missing.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. U.N. Squadron [CP-S No. 06] (1989) [CR]2. Carrier Airwing [CP-S No. 12] (1990)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]All ports were listed in USA version including European ports. Please refer to the original Capcom entry for Japanese ports.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo SNES [US] (September 1991) [Model SNS-E8][CR]Nintendo SNES [EU] (December 10, 1992) [Model SNSP-E8][CR]* Computers : [CR]Amstrad CPC [EU] (1990)[CR]Atari ST [EU] (1990)[CR]Sinclair ZX Spectrum [EU] (1990)[CR]Commodore C64 [US] [EU] (1990)[CR]Commodore Amiga [US] (1990)[CR]Amstrad CPC [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Atari ST [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Commodore C64 [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Commodore Amiga [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection" [CR]Sinclair ZX Spectrum [EU] (1991) "Capcom Collection"[CR]

game.name: U.S. Championship V'ball (US)
game.plot: U.S.Championship Beach Volley - V'Ball (c) 1988 Technos Japan Corp.[CR]The player takes control of a pair of beach bums named George and Michael who make their living playing beach volleyball against locals. One day, they find a flyer for a nationwide beach volleyball tournament offering the winning team a $2,500,000 cash prize.[CR]In single-player mode, one person controls both characters on a team. In two-player mode, the players either cooperate by playing on the same team or compete against each other by controlling opposing teams. The American version allows the game to be played by up to four players (if the cabinet allows it). The single-player mode consists of two cycles with four stages: the Minor Circuit and the Major Circuit. The stages in the game are Daytona Beach, New York, Los Angeles and Hawaii. After completing the Major Circuit, the player faces against the U.S. Navy team, set in a naval base.[CR]The controls consist of an eight directional joystick and two buttons for jumping and receiving. The characters perform several moves including power spiking, back spiking, jump-serving, blocking and diving.[CR]There are a few minor differences between the Japanese and American releases. The Japanese release features an opening cut-scene explaining the plot. Between matches, intermission sequences depict the main characters visiting a car dealership to purchase a vehicle. As the player progresses, the cars increase in quality, shifting from used cars to new cars during the Major Circuit. The American release removes these cut-scenes, but extends the multiplayer support to up to four players with multiple game modes: 1 or 2 players against the computer, 1-on-1, 2-on-1, or 2-on-2.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Game ID : TA-0025[CR]Main CPU : MOS Technology M6502 (@ 2 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 3.579545 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2151 (@ 3.579545 Mhz), OKI6295 (@ 8 Khz)[CR]Players : 4[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]U.S.Championship Beach Volley was released in December 1988.[CR]V'Ball stands for 'VolleyBall'.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Nintendo Famicom (1989, US : "Super Spike V'Ball", Japan : "US Championship V'Ball")[CR]

game.name: Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3 (rev 1.2)
game.plot: Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3 (c) 1995 Midway Mfg. Co.[CR]An update of "Mortal Kombat 3", with new characters added to the original MK3 cast. There are lots of other additions and goodies in the game (see Updates section (REV. 1.0)).[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Midway Wolf Unit Hardware[CR]Main CPU : TMS34010 (@ 6.25 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : ADSP2105 (@ 10 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : DMA-driven (@ 10 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2 [CR]Control : 8-Way Joystick [CR]Buttons : 6 [CR]= > [1] High Punch, [2] Block, [3] High Kick [CR]= > [4] Low Punch, [5] Low Kick, [6] Run[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3 was released in October 1995 in USA. [CR]If you look closely at Rain's name during demonstration you'll see it uses different font than all other fighters.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]This game is the same as "Mortal Kombat 3" except for the inclusion of :[CR]REV. 1.0 :[CR]* Jade, Kitana, Mileena, Scorpion, Reptile, Ermac, Classic Sub, Rain, and Human Smoke are all added (see bios above), and Robot Smoke is now a normal character.[CR]* Scorpion's Lair (Hell), Jade's Desert, Kahn's Kave, River Kombat (Waterfront), and Scislac Busorez (Blue Portal) stages added.[CR]* Computer intelligence increased.[CR]* 4 Player 2 on 2 Mode and 8 Player Tournament Mode Added.[CR]* Jump in Combo starters added.[CR]* Can uppercut through Scorpion's Lair to Kahn's Kave.[CR]* Bank and Smoke's Portal stages removed.[CR]* 2nd Master Added.[CR]* Endurance Rounds Added in Master and 2nd Master.[CR]* Stage fatalily in Scorpion's Lair added (and all of its accompanying secrets).[CR]* Classic Sub-Zero's Fats added.[CR]* Bug : Game will crash if Noob Saibot touches Sub-Zero's ice clone.[CR]* 'Winner fights Smoke' Kombat Kode effect altered : winner now fights Human Smoke rather than Robot Smoke.[CR]* Shang Tsung's morph now announces the character he morphs into.[CR]REV. 1.1 :[CR]* Supreme Demonstration icon selectable only through the 8-man tournament.[CR]REV. 1.2 :[CR]* CPU Pattern Fixed.[CR]* Bugs fixed.[CR]* More Kombat Kodes.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Secret EJB MENU:[CR]Press P1_BLOCK (x5), P2_BLOCK (x10), P1_BLOCK (x3), P2_BLOCK (x1), P1_BLOCK (x2), P2_BLOCK (x2), P1_BLOCK (x3), P2_BLOCK (x4)[CR]* Ultimate Kombat Kodes : The Ultimate Kombat Kodes appear at the single player game over screen. The following buttons control each box, from left to right : HP LP BL LK HK (1P side) HP LP BL LK HK (2P side). The numbers indicate how many times each button should be pressed to display the correct symbol in the box. A dash separates the 1P entries from the 2P entries :[CR]Play as Mileena - 22264-22264[CR]Play as Ermac - 12344-44321[CR]Play as Classic Subzero - 81835-81835[CR]* Kombat Kodes : Kombat Kodes are entered at the two player versus screen that appears after character selection. The following buttons control each box, from left to right : LP BL LK (player one side) LP BL LK (player two side). The numbers indicate how many times each button should be pressed to display the correct symbol in the box. A dash separates the player one entries from the player two entries. A message will appear when the match begins to confirm correct code entry...[CR]The Stages : [CR]002-003 - River Kombat (Waterfront)[CR]004-700 - Kahn's Kave [CR]050-050 - Noob Saibot Dorfen [CR]077-022 - The Bridge [CR]079-035 - Street [CR]091-190 - Bell Tower [CR]123-901 - Soul Chamber [CR]330-033 - Jade's Desert [CR]343-343 - Rooftop [CR]600-040 - Kombat Temple [CR]666-333 - The Graveyard [CR]666-444 - Scorpion's Lair (Hell)[CR]820-028 - The Pit 3 [CR]880-088 - Subway [CR]880-220 - Kahn's Tower (aka The Balcony)[CR]933-933 - Scislac Busorez (Blue Portal)[CR]Messages :[CR]004-400 - Whacha Gun Do ? - E.B.[CR]010-010 - Throwing Encouraged[CR]122-221 - Skunky!! - E.F.[CR]123-926 - There Is No Knowledge That Is Not Power[CR]282-282 - No Fear = EB Button, Skydive, Max Countdown[CR]448-844 - Don't Jump At Me - MXV[CR]550-550 - See The Mortal Kombat Live Tour[CR]717-313 - Rain Can Be Found In The Graveyard[CR]987-666 - Hold Flippers During Casino Run[CR]999-999 - Revision x.x[CR]Handicaps :[CR]033-000 - Player 1 Half Power [CR]000-033 - Player 2 Half Power[CR]707-000 - Player 1 Quarter Power[CR]000-707 - Player 2 Quarter Power[CR]020-020 - Blocking Disabled[CR]044-440 - Unikoriv Referri: Sans Power[CR]100-100 - Throwing Disabled[CR]Different Kombats :[CR]300-300 - Silent Kombat[CR]444-444 - Randper Kombat[CR]460-460 - Randper Kombat[CR]688-422 - Dark Kombat[CR]985-125 - Psycho Kombat[CR]Winner of this round battles :[CR]033-564 - Shao Khan[CR]205-205 - Human Smoke[CR]769-342 - Noob Saibot [CR]969-141 - Motaro [CR]4 Player 2 on 2 Kombat :[CR]227-227 - Explosive Kombat[CR]022-220 - Explosive Kombat/ Throwing Disabled[CR]Other Codes :[CR]466-466 - Unlimited Run[CR]642-468 - You Are Entering The Land Of Rellim (Play "Galaga")[CR]788-322 - Fast Uppercut Recovery Enabled[CR]987-123 - No Powerbars[CR]* Double stage (If a character is uppercutted, they will fly up to the other stage) :[CR]Scorpions Lair = > Kahn's Kave (Ultimate MK3 only)[CR]Subway = > Street[CR]Bank = > Rooftop (Original MK3 only)[CR]Soul Chamber = > Kahn's Tower (Balcony)[CR]* Random Select : To have the computer randomly select your character, press Up+Start on your side (player 1 on Kitana and player 2 on Scorpion).[CR]* Play as Human Smoke : select Smoke, then hold HP+HK+BL+RUN+Left until the match starts (Note : If playing as player two, press Right instead of Left).[CR]* Play forever : this code will allow you to continue playing Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3. The only catch is, you cannot die. When you beat the game, choose the goodie that lets you fight Ermac. Win the first round, and lose the second round on purpose. Win the third round and perform a mercy (hold RUN, DOWN(x3), release RUN), and then perform your characters animality. You will be taken to the 'choose your destiny' screen. Keep repeating the process, and you can rack up hundreds of wins.[CR]* Fatality - KITANA :[CR]1. (close) Run(x2), Block(x2), LK - Kitana reaches out and kisses her opponent, who then starts stretching up. Her opponent does this a few times, then explodes.[CR]2. (close) Back, Down, Forward(x2), HK - Kitana draws her fan and decapitates the opponent with one swipe. It's like the MKII head chop, but now it's more of an angle in the chop.[CR]* Fatality - REPTILE :[CR]1. (jump distance) Back, Forward, Down, Block - Reptile takes his mask off exposing his face. He lashes his tongue out and eats the head of his opponent. Then he continues and eats the torso and limbs, leaving the feet alone.[CR]2. (sweep) Hold Block, Forward(x2), Up(x2), release Block, HK - Reptile takes his mask off exposing his face. He opens his mouth and spits a big glob of acid onto his opponent. The acid burns down his opponent leaving a body without some skin, the acid left all over the ground. Then the body falls into a pile of slop.[CR]* Fatality - SONYA BLADE :[CR]1. (anywhere) Back, Forward, Down(x2), Run - Sonya blows a kiss at her opponent, turning him into a burning skeleton.[CR]2. (far) hold Run+Block, Up(x2), Back, Down, release Block+Run - Sonya blows a pink bubble at her opponent. Her opponent is engulfed in the bubble, which eventually collapses, crushing them.[CR]* Fatality - JAX : [CR]1. (close) Hold Block, Up, Down, Forward, Up, and release Block - Jax's arms form into long blades. He then cuts the opponent to pieces.[CR]2. (far) Run, Block, Run(x2), LK - Jax grows to an immense size and steps on his opponent.[CR]* Fatality - NIGHTWOLF :[CR]1. (one step back) Up(x2), Back, Forward, Block - Nightwolf causes a great light to engulf the opponent, which disintegrates them.[CR]2. (jump distance) Back(x2), Down, HP - Nightwolf summons lightning into his tomahawk. He then electrocutes the opponent.[CR]* Fatality - JADE : [CR]1. (close) Run(x3), Block, Run - Jade uppercuts her opponent up high, and holds her staff to her side, it glows, then her opponent falls right on the staff.[CR]2. (close) Hold Block, Up(x2), release Block, Down, Forward, HP - Jade sticks her staff into her opponent and starts to shake the staff and her opponent up and down. She does it so fast that her opponent blows up.[CR]* Fatality - SCORPION :[CR]1. (jump distance) Hold Block, Down(x2), Up, release Block, HK - Scorpion removes his mask exposing a skull head. His opponent screams, and then Scorpion set his opponent on fire.[CR]2. (close) Hold Block, Forward(x2), Down, Up, release Block, Run - Scorpion strikes his victory pose and then he teleports himself and his opponent to the Scorpion's Lair stage. Then multiple Scorpion clones come up and look at his opponent, then run at him/her and the screen goes dark, then you hear lots of punches, rips, and screams.[CR]* Fatality - KANO :[CR]1. (close) hold LP, Forward, Down(x2), Forward, release LP - Kano pulls his opponent's skeleton out through their mouth.[CR]2. (sweep) LP, Block(x2), HK - Kano fires a laser from his eye that heats up his opponent until they explode.[CR]* Fatality - MILEENA :[CR]1. (close) Down, Forward, Down, Forward, LP - Mileena removes her mask revealing her face and inhales her opponent, spitting out the bones. It's like the MKII Inhale, but now many more body parts come out. Most are rib cages and a few heads.[CR]2. (far) Back(x3), Forward, LK - Mileena opens her mouth, then swallows a jar of tacks. She then starts to spit them out at her victim.[CR]* Fatality - ERMAC : [CR]1. (close) Run, Block, Run(x2), HK - Ermac crouches and punches off the head of his opponent with a powerful uppercut.[CR]2. (sweep) Hold Block, Down, Up, release Block, Down(x3), Block - Ermac raises his hand, his opponent is then slammed multiple times and eventually explodes to pieces. [CR]* Fatality - CLASSIC SUB-ZERO : [CR]1. (close) Down(x3), Forward, HP - Classic Sub-Zero reaches for his opponent's head, the screen goes black and a big rip is heard as his opponent's head comes off. [CR]2. ??? [CR]* Fatality - SUB-ZERO :[CR]1. (close) Block(x2), Run, Block, Run - Sub-Zero grabs his opponent and lifts them over his head. He freezes them and proceeds to shatter them in a massive explosion and throws the ice and body parts to the ground.[CR]2. (sweep) Back(x2), Down, Back, Run - Sub-Zero blows a mist that freezes his opponent. They fall over and shatter.[CR]* Fatality - SEKTOR :[CR]1. (sweep) LP, Run(x2), Block - Sektor crushes his opponent in a huge clamp.[CR]2. (less jump distance) Forward(x3), Back, Block - Sektor uses a flame thrower on his opponent.[CR]* Fatality - SINDEL :[CR]1. (sweep) Run(x2), Block, Run, Block - Sindel coils her hair around her opponent. She then pulls her hair back, causing her opponent to go into a violent spin, sending blood and body parts everywhere.[CR]2. (close) Run, Block(x2), Run+Block - Sindel screams at her opponent, causing her opponent's skin to fly off.[CR]* Fatality - KURTIS STRYKER :[CR]1. (close) Down, Forward, Down, Forward, Block - Stryker plants explosives on his opponent and runs away just before they explode.[CR]2. (far) Forward(x3), LK - Stryker fires a tazer at his opponent, electrocuting them.[CR]* Fatality - CYRAX : [CR]1. (anywhere) Hold Block, Down(x2), Up, Down, release Block, HP - Cyrax's head spins like a helicopter. He flies up and comes down head first on his opponent. [CR]2. (close) Hold Block, Down(x2), Forward, Up, release Block, Run - Cyrax self-destructs, taking his opponent with him.[CR]* Fatality - KUNG LAO :[CR]1. (sweep) Forward(x2), Back, Down, HP - Kung Lao throws his hat. It makes four passes at his opponent, cutting them into pieces.[CR]2. (anywhere) Run, Block, Run, Block, Down - Kung Lao does his whirl spin. His opponent gets pulled in and is torn apart.[CR]* Fatality - KABAL :[CR]1. (sweep) Down(x2), Back, Forward, Block - Kabal plugs his respirator into his opponent. Their head inflates and they float off the screen where they explode.[CR]2. (close) Run, Block(x3), HK - Kabal removes his mask to reveal a hideous face and screams at his opponent. His opponent is so frightened that his/her soul jumps out of their body.[CR]* Fatality - SHEEVA :[CR]1. (close) Forward, Down(x2), Forward, LP - Sheeva pounds her opponent into the ground like a nail.[CR]2. (close) hold HK, Back, Forward(x2), release HK - Sheeva rips all her opponent's skin off.[CR]* Fatality - SHANG TSUNG :[CR]1. (close) hold LP, Down, Forward(x2), Down, release LP - Tsung creates a bed of spikes and throws his opponent onto them.[CR]2. (close) hold LP, Run, Block, Run, Block, release LP - Tsung levitates his opponent off the ground. He steals their soul and their remains fall to the ground in a green puddle.[CR]* Fatality - LIU KANG :[CR]1. (anywhere) Forward(x2), Down(x2), LK - Liu Kang disappears and reforms on his opponent as fire. His opponent is reduced to a burning skeleton.[CR]2. (anywhere) Hold Block, Up, Down, Up(x2), release Block, Block+Run - Liu Kang disappears and a "Mortal Kombat" machine falls on his opponent.[CR]* Fatality - SMOKE :[CR]1. (far) Hold Block, Up(x2), Forward, Down, Release Block - Smoke opens his chest and bombs pour out. The screen fades to a picture of the Earth just seconds before the Earth explodes.[CR]2. (jump distance) hold Run+Block, Down(x2), Forward, Up - Smoke drops an anarchist's bomb down his opponent's throat, causing them to explode.[CR]* Fatality - HUMAN SMOKE : [CR]1. (close) Run, Block, Run(x2), HK - Human Smoke crouches and punches off the head of his opponent with a powerful uppercut.[CR]2. ???[CR]* Fatality - STAGE :[CR]1) Bell Tower - the opponent falls seven stories onto a bed of spikes.[CR]2) Subway - the opponent is uppercutted into the far tracks where they are hit by an oncoming train.[CR]3) The Pit 3 - the opponent is knocked off the bridge into rotating blades and cut apart.[CR]4) Scorpion's Lair (Hell) - the opponent is knocked into a pool of lava.[CR]KITANA : Forward, Down(x2), LK[CR]REPTILE : Run, Block, Run, Block(x2)[CR]SONYA BLADE : Forward(x2), Down, HP[CR]JAX : Down, Forward, Down, LP[CR]NIGHTWOLF : Run(x2), Block[CR]JADE : Back, Forward, Down, Run[CR]SCORPION : Forward, Hold Block, Up(x2), Release Block, LP[CR]KANO : Hold Block, Up(x2), Back, Release Block, LK[CR]MILEENA : Down(x3), LP[CR]ERMAC : Run(x4), LK[CR]CLASSIC SUB-ZERO : Forward, Down, Forward(x2), HP[CR]SUB-ZERO : Back, Down, Forward(x2), HK[CR]SEKTOR : Run(x3), Down[CR]SINDEL : Down(x3), LP[CR]KURTIS STRYKER : hold Block, Forward, Up(x2), Release Block, HK[CR]CYRAX : Run, Block, Run[CR]KUNG LAO : Down(x2), Forward(x2), LK[CR]KABAL : Block(x2), HK[CR]SHEEVA : Down, Forward, Down, Forward, LP[CR]SHANG TSUNG : Hold Block, Up(x2), Back, Release Block, LP[CR]LIU KANG : Run, Block(x2), LK[CR]SMOKE : Forward(x2), Down, LK[CR]HUMAN SMOKE : Forward, Hold Block, Up(x2), Release Block, LP[CR]* CRISPY : After performing the stage fatality in Scorpions's Lair :[CR]Hold both HP buttons (Dan Forden voice)[CR]Hold both Run buttons (Shao Kahn voice)[CR]Hold both HP+Run buttons (Dan Forden + Shao Kanh voice)[CR]* Finish Him/Her - Mercy : (Anywhere) Hold Run, Down (x3), release Run.[CR]* Finish Him/Her - Animality (After Mercy) : [CR]KITANA : (one step back) Down(x4), Run - Kitana turns into a little rabbit, lets out a big growl, and then attacks her opponent in a spray of blood, moving her opponent off the screen.[CR]REPTILE : (close) Hold Block, Down(x3), Up, Release Block, HK - Reptile turns into a monkey and chases his opponent off the screen.[CR]SONYA BLADE : (close) hold LP, Back, Forward, Down, Forward, release LP - Sonya turns in to a large green bird and hovers over her opponent. She carries her opponent off screen where there is a crunching sound and bones fall back to the ground.[CR]JAX : (close) hold LP, Forward(x2), Down, Forward, release LP - Jax turns into a yellow lion and pounces on his opponent.[CR]NIGHTWOLF : (close) Forward(x2), Down(x2) - Nightwolf turns into a red wolf and pounces on his opponent.[CR]JADE : (close) Forward, Down, Forward(x2), LK - Jade turns into a cat and lets out a big growl. She jumps up and runs around on her opponent, making her opponent spin so fast that they're is spun into pieces.[CR]SCORPION : (close) Hold Block, Forward, Up(x2), Release Block, HK - Scorpion turns into a penguin, waddles under the opponent, and lays an egg. He then waddles away, and the egg starts to shake, and then explodes, blowing his opponent to pieces. [CR]KANO : (close) hold HP, Block(x3) release HP - Kano turns into an orange spider and crushes his opponent.[CR]MILEENA : (close) Forward, Down(x2), Forward, HK - Mileena turns into a skunk, and sprays her opponent with her smelly liquid, which is just green smoke. The opponent falls over to his/her death.[CR]ERMAC : ???[CR]CLASSIC SUB-ZERO : ???[CR]SUB-ZERO : (close) Hold Block, Forward, Up(x2), Release Block - Sub-Zero turns into a blue polar bear and pounces on his opponent.[CR]SEKTOR : (close) Forward(x2), Down, Up - Sektor turns into a giant purple bat. He flies to his opponent and decapitates them.[CR]SINDEL : (anywhere) Forward(x2), Hold Block, Up, Release Block, HP - Sindel turns into a purple wasp and carries her opponent off while stinging them.[CR]KURTIS STRYKER : (one step back) Run(x3), Block - Stryker turns into a red tyrannosaurus rex and bites his opponent in half.[CR]CYRAX : (close) Hold Block, Up(x2), Release Block, Down(x2) - Cyrax turns into a light-blue Shark. He swims off the screen then pops up behind his opponent and eats them.[CR]KUNG LAO : (close) Run(x4), Block - Kung Lao turns into a yellow leopard and pounces on his opponent.[CR]KABAL : (close) hold HP, Forward(x2), Down, Forward, release HP - Kabal turns into a green skeleton of a rhinoceros and butts his opponent into the air.[CR]SHEEVA : (close) Run, Block(x3) - Sheeva turns into a giant purple scorpion and stings her opponent, causing them to explode.[CR]SHANG TSUNG : (sweep) hold HP, Run(x3), release HP - Tsung turns into a large green cobra and devours his opponent.[CR]LIU KANG : (one step back) Down(x2), Up - Liu Kang turns into a giant green dragon and bites his opponent in half.[CR]SMOKE : (far) Down, Forward(x2), Block - Smoke turns into a black bull and rams his opponent off the screen.[CR]HUMAN SMOKE : ???[CR]* Finish Him/Her - Babality (don't use Block during the last round) :[CR]CLASSIC SUB-ZERO : ???[CR]CYRAX : Forward(x2), Back, HP[CR]ERMAC : ???[CR]HUMAN SMOKE : Down, Back(x2), Forward, HP[CR]JADE : Down(x2), Forward, Down, HK[CR]JAX : Down(x3), LK[CR]KABAL : Run(x2), LK[CR]KANO : Forward(x2), Down(x2), LK[CR]KITANA : Forward(x2), Down, Forward, HK[CR]KUNG LAO : Down, Forward(x2), HP[CR]LIU KANG : Down(x3), HK[CR]MILEENA : Down(x2), Forward(x2), HP[CR]NIGHTWOLF : Forward, Back, Forward, Back, LP[CR]REPTILE : Forward(x2), Back, Down, LK[CR]SCORPION : Down, Back(x2), Forward, HP[CR]SEKTOR : Back, Down(x3), HK[CR]SHANG TSUNG : Run(x3), LK[CR]SHEEVA : Down(x3), Back, HK[CR]SINDEL : Run(x3), Up[CR]SMOKE : Down(x2), Back(x2), HK[CR]SONYA BLADE : Down(x2), Forward, LK[CR]STRYKER : Down, Forward(x2), Back, HP[CR]SUB-ZERO : Down, Back(x2), HK[CR]* Finish Him/Her - Friendship (don't use Block during the last round) : [CR]KITANA : Down, Back, Forward(x2), LP - Kitana blows bubbles out of a bubble pipe and bottle.[CR]REPTILE : (close) Down, Forward(x2), Back, HK - Reptile takes out a box and turns the knob many times. Then the top opens revealing a big lizard head. The head scares his opponent who then runs off.[CR]SONYA BLADE : (sweep) Back, Forward, Back, Down, Run - Sonya does her normal win pose and flowers suddenly bloom across the screen.[CR]JAX : LK, Run(x2), LK - Jax takes out a jump rope and starts skipping.[CR]NIGHTWOLF : (past sweep) Run(x3), Down - Nightwolf turns into Raiden. A "Mortal Kombat II" machine falls below him. At the bottom of the screen are the words : "I have never seen a Kano transformation!" OR "No, but I know how to do a Raiden transformation!".[CR]JADE : Back, Down, Back(x2), HK - Jade uses her staff as a pogo stick.[CR]SCORPION : (close) Back, Forward(x2), Back, LK - Scorpion takes out a box and turns the knob many times. Then the top opens revealing a big skull head. The head scares his opponent who then runs off.[CR]KANO : LK, Run(x2), HK - Kano munches on some bubble gum and blows a large bubble, which eventually bursts all over his face.[CR]MILEENA : Down(x2), Back, Forward, HP - Mileena takes out a mirror, and takes off her mask. She then looks into the mirror with her ugly face and the mirror shatters. [CR]ERMAC : ???[CR]CLASSIC SUB-ZERO : ???[CR]SUB-ZERO : LK, Run(x2), Up - Sub-Zero engulfs himself into a snowman.[CR]SEKTOR : (half screen) Run(x4), Down - A Ring-the-Bell game pops up and Sektor plays it.[CR]SINDEL : Run(x5), Up - Sindel kicks a ball over the opponent and makes a 'Goal' sign. She then says, 'That was fun!'. [CR]KURTIS STRYKER : LP, Run(x2), LP - Stryker blows a whistle and takes out a stop sign. The other kombatants (only those NOT in Ultimate MK3) run by and Stryker directs them to the other side.[CR]CYRAX : Run(x3), Up - Cyrax does a little dancing.[CR]KUNG LAO : (past sweep) Run, LP, Run, LK - Kung Lao tosses his hat off screen. A dog chases after the hat. Kung Lao covers his eyes as there is a cry off screen, then sadly shakes his head.[CR]KABAL : (past sweep) Run, LK, Run(x2), Up - Kabal roasts a marshmallow on his hook sword.[CR]SHEEVA : Forward(x2), Down, Forward, HP - Sheeva holds a stick in each hand and balances a plate on each.[CR]SHANG TSUNG : LK, Run(x2), Down - Tsung turns into the character from "Joust" and hops off.[CR]LIU KANG : Run(x3), Down+Run - A film screen pops up and Liu Kang makes a shadow puppet of a dragon.[CR]SMOKE : (far) Run(x3), HK - An enormous brass horn comes out of Smoke's chest, and he blares a note.[CR]HUMAN SMOKE : ???[CR]* SHAO KAHN'S LOST TREASURES : After you beat Shao Kahn, you can choose a icons...[CR]Novice (01-04), Warrior (01-07), Master 1 (01-10), Master 2 (01-11), 8 player tournament (01-12)[CR]01) MK Dragon : Tournament Outcome[CR]02) MK Logo : Rellim Ohcanep (Play Galaga)[CR]03) Yin-Yang : Battle with ERMAC[CR]04) Number three : Battle with NOOB SAIBOT[CR]05) Question Mark : Random select[CR]06) Lightning Bolt : Fatality Demonstration One[CR]07) Goro : Fatality Demonstration Two[CR]08) Raiden : Fatality Demonstration Three[CR]09) Shao Kahn : NOOB SAIBOT / ERMAC endurance[CR]10) Skull : MK2 Classic Endurance Kombat (Classic Sub-Zero and Human Smoke)[CR]11) Question Mark : Mega Endurance Kombat (Noob Saibot, Classic Sub-Zero, Human Smoke, Ermac and Mileena)[CR]12) Question Mark : Supreme Demonstration[CR]Hidden treasures : Fatality Demonstration Four and Five, another ?[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.name: Ultimate Tennis
game.plot: Ultimate Tennis (c) 1993 Art & Magic.[CR]In 1993, the first Art & Magic's game has been compared with a tornado in the arcade's world. Based on a clever system of scrolling planes this game looked like a 3D game. The graphic's quality and the extremely good gameplay pushed "Ultimate Tennis" to the 2nd place in Germany and to the 14th place in the Japanese charts and was successfully diffused all around the world : 5.000 boards have been sold worldwide and among them more than 500 boards in Japan![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12.5 Mhz), TMS34010 (@ 5 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : OKI6295 (@ 8.08 Khz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Even if titlescreen says 1993, Ultimate Tennis was released in January 1994.[CR]Art and Magic was founded in 1992 by Yves Grolet and Franck Sauer, respectively the coder and the graphics artist behind some of the most technically advanced Amiga titles of all time : UNREAL by Ubi Soft (1990) and AGONY by Psygnosis (1992) which is also the first title published under the Art and Magic logo.[CR]Yves Grolet started his career on the Commodore 64 in 1986 at only 19 developing 2 titles: the graphical adventure NO published by Lankhor and the conversion of Iron Lord by Ubi Soft.[CR]After Art and Magic Yves founded the PC adventure games developer Appeal S.A. in 1995 and released OUTCAST after 4 years of work, and in 2002 he became CEO of elseWhere entertainment.[CR]Ultimate Tennis was their first arcade game, as they were still trying to adapt to their new platform, digitised sprites (all palette swaps of the same footage) were used as a proof of concept - later the artists would develop their caricature style to make cel-animated sprites. Approximately 5,000 units were produced.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Artwork : Franck Sauer, Iwan Scheer[CR]Software : Yann Robert, Yves Grolet[CR]Music : Franck Sauer, Christian Dutilleux[CR]Starring : Eric Dardenne[CR]Hardware designer : Deltatec[CR]Manufacturing : Deltatec[CR]

game.name: Ultra X Weapons / Ultra Keibitai
game.plot: Ultra Keibitai (c) 1995 Banpresto.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SSV system.[CR]Main CPU : V60 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : ES5506 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Ultra Keibitai was released in January 1995 in Japan.[CR]The title of the game translates from Japanese as 'Ultra Guards'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as Ultra X Weapons. You can change the Region via the dipswitches setting.[CR]This game is based on 'Ultraman', a famous Japanese live-action superhero series that has had numerous sequels and spin-offs since its debut in the 1960s. Generally, the main character is a normal human who uses an alien device to transform into a giant red-and-silver (sometimes with blue) creature called an Ultraman to combat alien monsters with the help of a special military team. Some of the subsequent shows in the series include 'Ultraseven', 'Ultraman Leo', 'Ultraman Taroh', and 'Ultraman Tiga'.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]A special version of the game was sent to the GAMEST magazine for review. This version has a different build date than the public release. Changes are unknown.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Developed by Seta.[CR]Planner: Takehiko Hoashi[CR]Programmer: Noboru Harada[CR]CG designer: Yasuhiko Kikuchi[CR]Graphic designers: Kohzoh Igarashi, Shingo Aoyama[CR]Hardware engineer: Masahiro Yamaguchi[CR]Video chip designer: Kenji Oiyama[CR]Sound: Opus Corp.[CR]Music: Masanao Akahori[CR]Sound effects: Jun Enoki, Satoshi Ohta[CR]Supervisor: Tsuburaya Pro., Hiroshi Funai[CR]

game.name: Undercover Cops (World)
game.plot: Undercover Cops (c) 1992 Irem.[CR]Dr. Clayborn and his henchmen have taken control of the city and Commissioner Gordon (no, Batman is not in the game) made one last plea for help and called three of New York's Finest undercover cops : Bubba, an ex-professional football player; Flame, a former Miss America; and Claude, a retired philosophy teacher. They must fight every lackey and vanquish Dr. Clayborn in order to restore law and order to the city. Very fun beat-em-up where almost anything can be used as a weapon; fish, rocks, i-beams, cars, etc.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Irem M-92 system hardware[CR]Main CPU : V33 (@ 9 Mhz), V30 (@ 7.15909 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2151 (@ 3.579545 Mhz), GA20 (@ 3.579545 Mhz)[CR]Players : 3[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2 (ATTACK, JUMP)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Undercover Cops was released in July 1992.[CR]The Police 'car' at the end of Undercover Cops looks (and acts) just like "Moon Patrol", which is also from Irem.[CR]On the small red TV items, you can see that they have a picture of the boss from Stage 1 of "R*Type"![CR]Soundtrack releases:[CR]Undercover Cops - Victor Entertainment - VICL-5180 - Dec 16, 1992[CR]Manga releases:[CR]Undercover Cops 1 Beach Koba - Shinseisha - Aug 30, 1993[CR]Undercover Cops 2 Beach Koba - Shinseisha - Feb 10, 1995[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]The US version is missing ROSA's running+jump+attack.[CR]Name changes between JAPAN and WORLD version :[CR]Zan Takahara / Claude[CR]Matt Gables / Bubba[CR]Rosa Felmond / Flame[CR]The Japanese version has also different music.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Creator : Meeher[CR]Designers : Akio, Susumu, Kozo, Nob[CR]Programmers : Teroling, Danger Nao[CR]Sound : Hiyamuta (Hiya!)[CR]Character voices : Nukegara, Muttershi, Fuku Chan, Kiki[CR]American staff : Steve, Drew, Max[CR]Publicity staff : S. Sakomizu[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (March 3, 1995) "Undercover Cops [Model SHVC-AUCJ-JPN]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]PC [MS Windows, Online] [EU] (December 9, 2011) "IREM Arcade Hits" by DotEmu [CR]Apple MacIntosh [Online] [US] (August 21, 2011) "Irem Arcade Hits" by DotEmu [CR]PC [Desura] [US] (November 2, 2013) "IREM Arcade Hits" by Plug In Digital[CR]

game.name: Vanguard (SNK)
game.plot: Vanguard (c) 1981 SNK.[CR]Vanguard is a scrolling space shooter (some levels are horizontal, some are diagonal, and some are vertical). Shoot down enemies with your laser. Keep a close eye on your ever decreasing fuel gauge, luckily each enemy that you destroy will add to your remaining fuel. Find the energy pods to be temporarily invulnerable; the energy pods will also increase your fuel level. At the end of each level you must defeat a boss that is guarded by two moving force fields with holes in them. The computer will announce the name of the each zone using some nifty early 80's synthesized speech. The different levels include Mountain Zone, Rainbow Zone, Styx Zone, Rainbow Zone 2, Stripe Zone, Rainbow Zone 3, Bleak Zone, and the City of Mystery.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : MOS Technology M6502 (@ 930 Khz)[CR]Sound Chips : Custom (@ 930 Khz), (2x) SN76477 (@ 930 Khz)[CR]Screen orientation : Vertical[CR]Video resolution : 224 x 256 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 61.25 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 64[CR]Players : 2 [CR]Control : 8-way joystick [CR]Buttons : 4[CR]= > [1] Fire Left, [2] Fire Right, [3] Fire Down, [4] Fire Up[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Vanguard was released in July 1981 in Japan and put SNK on the map in North America.[CR]Vanguard is the first color game from SNK and it was one of the first shoot-em-ups with an 8-way directional fire.[CR]The starting music is inspired by the 'Star Trek: The Motion Picture' soundtrack (release date is 1979), and later became the theme song to the 1987-1994 television series 'Star Trek: The Next Generation'. [CR]The music that plays when you get the power-up is 'Vultan's Theme: Attack of the Hawk Men' from the 'Flash Gordon' soundtrack.[CR]A Vanguard unit appears in the 1982 movie 'Jekyll & Hyde... Together Again'.[CR][B]Scoring[/B][CR]Mist - Bouncing starship : 70 points[CR]Harley - Fighter : 50 points[CR]Helm - White UFO : 80 points[CR]Amno - Pink UFO : 100 points[CR]Base I, II, III - Buildings : 100 - 400 points[CR]Garine - Bouncing aliens : 100 - 400 points[CR]Barrier - Energy barrier : 800 points[CR]Kemlus - "C" shaped worms : 100 - 400 points[CR]Romeda - Arrow shaped ships : 100 points[CR]Gond - Boss at end of round : 1,000 - 8,000 points[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* When you start the game, your fighter will be at the left side of the screen. Keep in mind, this is a scrolling game. This means you can go no faster then the right side and no slower then the left side. You can, however, vary your speed in-between by pushing the joystick back and forth. The biggest key in getting through this game is learning how to use the joystick to speed up and slow down because you will sometimes be put into some very tight areas that will require precision joystick control. Here are some strategies for getting through them. There is no break between the areas, but you can pretty much tell what area you are in by the landscape and/or the enemies.[CR]MOUNTAIN ZONE : This zone is pretty straightforward. The mountain is wide enough for you to maneuver out of harms way.[CR]1) There should be no reason that you can't go through both areas energized. The energy stations are abundant in the mountain zone.[CR]2) The Harley's like to group up in packs of five or six. They will fire on you and an occasional Harley will break from the pack to try to ram your fighter. They usually stay on one level and don't move around a lot. Very easy to evade.[CR]3) The Mist's are a different matter. They move around all over the area and they are rather difficult to hit. You will have to use your lasers from different sides very effectively.[CR]RAINBOW ZONE : In these zones you will be going diagonal up or diagonal down. The first part only has three aliens while the second part of the zone has six aliens moving up and down.[CR]1) On the diagonal up parts, get your fighter in between the second and third aliens during the first part. Reverse this on the diagonal down parts.[CR]2) On the second part, you will have to get in between the fourth and fifth aliens. You may have to use your top laser to clear out the alien above since the top three alternate with the bottom three. Reverse this on the diagonal down parts.[CR]STYX ZONE : There are no energy stations in this zone so you will have to do some quick maneuvering and firing in all directions. This area also narrow significantly. Use the same tactics from the Mountain Zone.[CR]STRIPE ZONE : You only have to deal with ground targets in this zone. This, though, is the problem since those targets are clustered very close together.[CR]1) You should be able to go through this area energized since energy stations are abundant in the lower parts of this zone.[CR]2) If you aren't energized, make sure you decided quickly to go high or low. If you go high, you deal with bases and Garines (bouncing aliens). This can be rough if you mistime it. The bottom has more targets but you must destroy the barrier. You do this by destroying the upper or lower stand that fires it up.[CR]3) This zone lasts a while but the pattern remains the same.[CR]BLEAK ZONE : You will be going up instead of sideways. The scrolling now is you can't go faster then the top of the screen or slower then the bottom of the screen.[CR]1) Enemies on this screen are actually pretty easy to get through. Just stay in the middle and keep firing. The Romeda may give you trouble since they like to fire left diagonal shots.[CR]2) If you go into the debris left from the Kemlus, a backward 'C' will surround your fighter and you will get 1090 points. You can do this three times. After the third time, if you try this, your fighter will be destroyed.[CR]CITY OF MYSTERY : This is for all the marbles. There are many hazards to avoid as you try to take out Gond.[CR]1) First, as you enter there are lasers to your left and right. You must quickly get into the second part. Gond is protected by two layers that have openings. These openings line up for only brief moments. Try to take shots through this opening.[CR]2) After a short amount of time, walls will close behind your fighter. You only have a limited amount of time because there are five walls and if they close before you take out Gond, you lose your fighter.[CR]3) The only good thing is if you fail to take out Gond, you advance to the next round. Of course, you don't get the bonus for Gond.[CR]4) After you make it through each set of cave one and cave two, the action gets faster.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Vanguard (1981)[CR]2. Vanguard II (1984)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]NOTE: To see ports released in North America, please see the Centuri entry.[CR]* Consoles :[CR]Atari 2600 [JP] (1983)[CR]

game.name: Vasara
game.plot: 婆裟羅 (c) 2000 Visco Corp.[CR](Vasara)[CR]Vertical shoot'em up with three selectable characters and nice manga style cut scene.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU: V60 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips: ES5506 (@ 16 Mhz)[CR]Players: 2[CR]Control: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons: 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Vasara was released in August 2000.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Good Ending : Clear stage 5 without continuing play, or clear stage 5 with continuing play over 10 times, or clear stage 5 with slashing all Bushous.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Vasara (2000)[CR]2. Vasara 2 (2001)[CR]

game.name: Vendetta (World, 4 Players, ver. T)
game.plot: Vendetta (c) 1991 Konami.[CR]Export version.
